The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid)
took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Has the minister received a high level tutorial from her department on today's ANZ figures for job ads? Does the minister acknowledge that job ads are now at their lowest level since January 1994, that job ads have now fallen for four consecutive months and this is the first such sequence since the four months ended December 1991? Given the government's back‐pedalling on the purported employment benefits of the workplace relations bill, how is the government going to reverse this disastrous trend? Where are the jobs going to come from and when will they materialise?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. His reference to a high class tutorial comes from my using that remark in a Senate estimates committee on Friday. Simply to make the point: every month when the labour force statistics come out some of the most talented people, the people most equipped to discuss unemployment trends and statistics, come up to the office with an embargoed copy of those statistics and we discuss the pros and cons of what is happening in the labour market.

answer.para:
Has that happened today with respect to the release of some ANZ material? No, so I cannot give you any further information on that matter. But, more importantly, Senator Bishop, you go to one of the most important questions facing this country; that is, where are the jobs going to come from and how are we going to generate them? There are two things to tell you with respect to that. First, they are certainly not going to come through a continuation of the make work schemes that the previous government—of which I accept you were not a member—wasted so much money on. That government spent something
like $700 million or $800 million in the last financial year on the three least effective brokered programs, programs with effectiveness outcome levels varying between the low 20s and low 30s. If you average that out at a 30 per cent effectiveness rate, you chucked 70 per cent of that $700 million to $800 million down the drain.

So the first thing we are going to do is we are going to put the money that we have available for labour market programs and training into a new scheme, taking the best of Working Nation—the bit we think did work, the one on one case management—and building on it very substantially; and discarding the worst of Working Nation. So we will spend the labour market program money that we have far more effectively than your colleagues' previous government did, with a view to making sure, as best as possible, that when people get the benefit of labour market assistance they end up in a real job.

But the question of the creation of real jobs, as you probably realise, Senator—although I know some of your colleagues do not—is an across government concern. In fact, it is an across the nation concern. You asked me how we are going to generate the real jobs into which people will go. Even given that we are revamping and improving the efficiency of the labour market programs, the jobs have to be there to put them into. I see you nodding and you understand that—I know that some of your colleagues do not.

Let me tell you, Senator Bishop, that you say that we have walked away from the contribution that we believe a more flexible market will make, but nobody says it is not going to make any contribution and we think it will make a contribution at least. I do not think even you deny that. More importantly, one of the best things we can do to create real jobs is get the budget back into black, clean up Beazley's bankcard, the $8 billion deficit that you left us with, and give confidence to the business community to generate real jobs.

If the business community and the financial markets can see that this government is prepared to make the hard decisions to clean up the mess that you made, we have a really good chance of doing things like keeping
interest rates down, building business confidence and generating real jobs. That is the first thing we want to do: get the budget back into black. You have an opportunity, Senator Bishop, in your caucus to convince your colleagues that they should do exactly as the Prime Minister says; and, that is, after the by‐election, get out of the way and let us do the job.
(Time expired)
.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the ANZ figures, Minister, will you now, for the first time since you became minister for employment, ask for written advice from your department on their projections for unemployment based on the coalition‐Democrat workplace relations deal and the terrible trend revealed by today's ANZ figures?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para:
—Senator Bishop, it might be of some surprise to you to understand that this government, unlike the previous government, works as a team. I have tried to explain it to you and I will take the opportunity to do it again. I speak to my department regularly, at least every month, in a fairly detailed way on unemployment issues and trends. That is what I just told you in the first answer. I do not need to ring up and say, `Please, could I have it in writing?' I speak to these people regularly and focus quite specifically on these issues when the labour force survey is released every month. I do not think you can necessarily put any great spin on that, which you are trying to do—I think it absolutely falls on deaf ears. This is unlike the previous government where then Minister Faulkner could not work with then Minister Beddall to such a degree that the cabinet was torn to shreds and someone else had to be given the job. Treasury looks after forecasts for this government.
(Time expired)

talker.role: Minister for the Environment)

talk.start.para:
—by leave—I should have explained this at the start, Madam President, but I was distracted in a negotiation that I had commenced with Senator Bolkus. —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to yesterday's release of the Commonwealth Bank HIA affordability index for the September quarter which indicated that buying the family home is at its most affordable level for two years, and notably in Victoria, since the index's inception in 1984. Could the minister please confirm whether this is in fact the case, and whether similar affordability figures to that in Victoria were recorded in other states? Could the minister also outline the factors which have lead to this good news for home buyers?

answer.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferguson for that important question which is of considerable interest to all first home buyers. You will be aware, Madam President, that home affordability figures released yesterday by the HIA were indeed welcome news for home buyers and families, especially first home buyers.

answer.para: According to the HIA housing report, in the September quarter of 1996 housing became nearly 10 per cent more affordable for the average Australian first home buyer. The loan repayment needed on a typical first home mortgage fell from 20.7 per cent of household income in the June quarter of 1996 to 18.9 per cent in the September quarter. This has contributed to the figures which show that housing is now more affordable than at any time since mid‐1994.

For Victoria, as Senator Ferguson said, the index shows that housing is indeed now more affordable than at any time since the index was first introduced in 1984. Lower interest rates and higher family incomes helped increase housing affordability by 10 per cent in Melbourne and by 13.5 per cent in the rest of the state.

In South Australia and in the ACT record affordability was also achieved. Affordability for Brisbane is the best it has been for a long
time and housing in New South Wales is now more affordable than at any time in the last two years. A major contributing factor to these figures is the lowering of interest rates which has occurred since the March election and the coalition's victory.

talk.start.para: —Because of low inflation and low wage levels.

—When this government came to office, Senator Sherry, you might be interested to record, the standard variable home mortgage rate charged by the big banks was 10.5 per cent. This has now fallen to 9.25 per cent, a fall of 1¼ percentage points.

answer.para: We are now seeing, partly as a result of competition and partly because of the economic strategy developed by the government and particularly as outlined in the budget, some major lenders offering the lowest home mortgage rates since the mid‐1970s. These reductions, which occurred after the September quarter, should help to make housing even more affordable.
In view of the comments coming from the other side, we may reflect on how this compares with Labor's woeful record. The current mortgage rate charged by the big four banks is 9.25 per cent.

talk.start.para: —The same position as it was in 1994, as I recall.

—Under Labor, Senator Collins, seeing you are calling out, the average was 12.75 per cent, more than one‐third higher than at present. Under Labor, home mortgage rates peaked at a whopping 17 per cent. As I said last week, over the last two and a half years under Labor, the only way that mortgage rates went was up and up. This is not surprising because over this time official interest rates went up as well. In fact, official interest rates went up to 7.5 per cent.

answer.para: Labor is the high interest rate party. It is a high interest rate party because you like big deficits, you like building up debt—and that amounts to a lot of pressure on interest rates. We are the low interest rate side of politics. We take the pressure off interest rates by tackling the deficit that we inherited. We want to give families and small business a long awaited break for the better.

talk.start.para: —Can't you try to be a bit more enthusiastic about your own Dorothy.
—If Labor is serious about continuing to take the pressure off interest rates, Senator Faulkner, and helping families and small business, it will pass our budget—and pass it soon.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that the government is proposing to cut up to $177 million in tied funding for government schools over the next four years based on the claimed savings to state and territory governments when a child moves from the government to the non‐government sector? Will this not inevitably lead to a deterioration in the quality of the public education system?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —The short answer is that it will not but let me expand on that answer for you. You will be aware of the new schools policy instituted by the previous Labor government—your party. You might not agree, as I would put to you, that it was unfair and discriminatory. That policy restricted the ability of parents to choose non‐government education, and it discriminated against parents whose children were in schools that had their funding limited regardless of the needs of that school. We thought that was an unfair policy and that was why we said we would get rid of it and why we will get rid of it.

answer.para: The policy did not succeed, however, in preventing parent choice because the proportion of students in non‐government schools nonetheless increased from 26.4 per cent in 1986 to 29 per cent in 1995.

talk.start.para: —Make up your mind; which one was it?

—Senator, for your benefit, in case you could not hear over the people in front of you yelling, the proportion of students in non‐government schools increased from 26.4 per cent in 1986 to 29 per cent in 1995.

break.para: The policy of the government—and I answered a question on this the other day—is to allow parents to choose the appropriate school for their child. We think that is the appropriate way to go—whether that school is a government or a non‐government school.

In view of the Commonwealth's national leadership role in school education, the government has rejected the recommendations of the Commission of Audit that schools funding be handed back to the states and territories—and I think they recommended at the same time that it be reduced by 10 per cent. The government is instead working with the states and territories to improve the quality of education provided to all students and to allow parents choice in education.

The government does not favour one sector over the other. Commonwealth funding will follow the student, as I explained in the Senate last week. The budget provided for the enrolment benchmark adjustment that would reduce the incentive of the states and territories to shift students to non‐government schools. It is a perfectly simple matter for people to try to get across—perhaps it is not as simple as one might imagine in the beginning but it is, in the end, pretty simple: what the states are trying to do is shift the share of students over to the Commonwealth.

Why are they trying to do that? They are trying to do that because the Commonwealth funds to a larger extent the students in non‐government schools, and that is why the states are interested in shifting the share of students over that way. That is absolutely why they are interested in doing that, and that is why we are keen to put a stop to that. It is estimated that since 1983 the shift of students to non-government schools has saved the states and territories more than $3 billion.

We have an important commitment to government schools and we believe that, if you take into account the specific purpose payments and the FAGS, students in government schools will actually get a per capita increase. They are calculations done on estimations, I accept that, but that is what we believe will happen. Australia's 10,000 schools will receive an estimated increase in funding of $1.5 billion over the next four
years. We are determined to see that the states accept their responsibility and to remove an incentive for them to off‐load students out of their schools into non‐government schools for the simple reason that the Commonwealth will then foot the bill. We think that is inappropriate.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Do the figures you are using, which are those used by Dr Kemp last Friday, take account of the flow‐on effects of the $1.5 billion cut to financial assistance grants announced at the last Premiers Conference? And how do you explain the discrepancy between Dr Kemp's figures and your own department's estimate, given at the estimates hearings, of a total increase for schools funding of only $128 million over the next four years?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —Senator, if Dr Kemp is using some different figures from those put by the department, I will get the two figures together and I will come back and give you an explanation of what the difference is. Okay?
—You are just not up with the facts.
—I don't know which figures he used.
—You don't know, period.
—Order! Senator Car! Senator Vanstone!
—You are out of touch with the reality around you. Get some reality into it!
—You don't know.
—Go and take a cold shower. Get some reality.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, you have completed the answer and should not be interjecting across the chamber. Senator Carr, you should desist.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, and it concerns small business. Will the minister inform the Senate
of the findings of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force, which released its report
Time for business
last Friday? What has been the reaction to the report, and what actions will the government be taking to further deliver on the commitment made by the government to this crucial sector of the Australian economy?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para:
—I thank the honourable senator for his question. This is an important matter and good news for small business after the long drought of Labor. Last Friday the Small Business Deregulation Task Force did present its report
Time for business
to the Prime Minister in Sydney. That task force, senators will remember, was established on 2 May, which delivered on a commitment made by the government in its policy, a new deal for small business.

answer.para: The report is the result of six months of intensive research and consultation, including talks with 250 small business operators, industry associations and government officials, as well as receiving the analysis of some 366 submissions. The release of the report demonstrates the depth of the government's commitment to Australian small business.

The report contains 62 recommendations addressing a wide range of small business concerns and makes some practical recommendations to reduce paperwork and the compliance burden, which will allow small business to get on and grow and to employ. Issues identified in the report include taxation, employment regulations, statistics, housing, chemicals, food, environment, provision of information, reducing government focus, government purchasing, monitoring and reporting arrangements as well as others.

The government will be considering the task force recommendations carefully over the next few months. The Prime Minister indicated on Friday that the government will outline a comprehensive response to the report by no later than the middle of February. He is also announcing today some immediate measures to assist small business.

It is pleasing to see the reaction to the report by business groups and commentators.
I remind you of that by the comments of the Housing Industry Association Ltd, which said:

The Small Business Taskforce is to be applauded on its Report to the Commonwealth Government. The Taskforce consulted widely and as a result, the report captures the real regulatory concerns facing small business in their day‐to‐day operation.
The Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia said:
The report by the Small Business Deregulation Taskforce is a victory for common sense and will provide real gains for small business if the recommendations are adopted . . .
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said:

The ACCI strongly supports the thrust of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force's recommendations for action to reduce the burden of compliance on small business . . . The ACCI congratulates the Small Business Deregulation Taskforce on their thorough examination of the issues and on their practical recommendations for reform.
The Motor Trades Industry Association said:

The initiative of the Coalition Government in proposing, as an election commitment, to establish the Task Force, the action of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs in quickly moving to undertake this important work and the dedication of the Task Force members in reporting in a timely fashion are all deserving of high praise.

This is an example of government working for the benefit of small business—small business which is so critical to the economic and employment future of Australia. It now has in place a government that understands its problems and will deliver to enable a better outcome for small business, with benefits that naturally flow to all Australians.

question.speaker: Calvert, Sen Paul

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the minister: have there been any other favourable reactions to the report?

question.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —The mirth from the other side is interesting because one of the favourable responses was from Senator Cook. Senator Cook took a long time to say it—13 years of Labor government—but now we are in office he said:

answer.para:
The report goes on to make some useful recommendations in terms of the regulatory culture that exists within government and further work that
needs to be done in implementing the recommendations.

Isn't it fascinating? They had 13 years to do something about it for the benefit of small business, they did nothing and, suddenly, from opposition, Senator Cook recognises that small business does have a problem with compliance. Yes, it does have a problem with compliance because it is still operating under Labor's legacy. The income tax act tripled in size under Labor—1,300 pages to 3,700 pages; provisional tax went up; bankruptcies reached record levels. I am pleased that Senator Cook has finally realised what good government can produce.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Does the minister acknowledge that the OECD data which she relied on in her Higher Education Budget Statement to justify dramatic increases to HECS is unreliable? Has the minister taken steps to advise her ERC colleagues that the figures they were provided with were dodgy? Will the minister now seek reconsideration of the government's ill‐informed decision to make Australia one of the most expensive countries in the world in which to study at a public university?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator, for that question. I do not know whether you were paying attention on the last sitting day when I took the opportunity during the adjournment debate to indicate that I had looked at the table from which the department drew the figures that were used in the budget statement. I agreed that that was not the best basis on which to make international comparisons. I made that perfectly clear.

answer.para:
What you perhaps get wrong, if I may suggest it, by the inference in your question, is that these figures were used in some way to justify the proposed changes to HECS in Australia, as if somehow the ERC and cabinet sat around and said, `What does everyone else do? Hell, let's go along that line.' If that is the suggestion you are putting, it is an incorrect suggestion. Those figures were used merely to fill in the picture and give an indication of what charges were elsewhere. So
the figures were not used as a basis for the decisions themselves.

Let me tell you what was the basis for the decision to increase the HECS contribution, and I have probably got enough time to outline why we thought we would shift to a differentiated HECS as well, why we think that is fairer and more equitable. The first thing to consider is: why have an increase in the HECS contribution in any event? Students get an enormous private benefit from graduating from university. You know that, I know that and all of your party knows that. That is why your party introduced the higher education contribution scheme. It is a recognition that universities have a private benefit and a public benefit. The HECS charge is meant to be an acknowledgment of the private benefit.

We believe that the private benefit is not adequately recognised in the HECS contribution paid thus far. Senator, you might like to look at the World Bank report which was very kindly drawn to my attention by Senator Stott‐Despoja, which points out that, with the quantity of people going to university from higher socioeconomic groups, the subsidy of tuition fees by the Commonwealth is redistributing funds to the wealthier in the community. You might like to take that into account as well, although that was not in my mind or drawn to my attention when we were making the decision to increase the contribution.

But it does bear repeating and understanding that roughly 15 per cent of Australians in the work force have been to university; 25 per cent of school leavers now go to university. When I attended a speech day for one of Adelaide's best private schools on Saturday, I was told that the percentage from that school who go to university is 85 per cent. That was the percentage from a wealthier private school. So if you want to maintain a situation where we should continue to subsidise the tuition fees of children of wealthy people and you do not think we should ask for a greater contribution from those students, then you run out and argue that case. But I am going to run out and argue the other case—that these people get an enormous private benefit. They are very substantially
subsidised by the taxpayer and it is fair to ask for a higher contribution.

With respect to the differentiated HECS, we have picked up the recommendations of former Labor premier Neville Wran, who recognised that it is completely unfair and inequitable to charge the same per annum contribution of a teacher with a low cost course at a lower income later in life, as it is to ask of a doctor with a high cost course and a higher income later in life. Senator, if you want to tell teachers they should pay the same as doctors, you go to it. But you won't find me with you.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question. There is no doubt, minister, that the budget statement seeks to make a case based in part upon the international comparisons of cost. Isn't it true, minister, that your department advised you last week that the information cited in the budget statement for the United States and Japan was `imperfect' and that the comparison with Denmark was `inappropriate'? What action have you taken or will you take in the light of this advice?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —On the last sitting day of this chamber, Thursday, I came into this chamber and gave a clear indication that the table the department was relying on was inadequate. I gave the advice that was offered to me by the department as a consequence of Senator Stott Despoya's question and the table. I do not see that there is much more I can possibly give you, Senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools. Does the Minister for Schools stand by his repeated assertions that 30 per cent of Australian 14-year-olds lack basic literacy skills? I refer the minister to the report by Mr Brian Toohey in the
Herald-Sun
newspaper at the weekend and on the ABC Radio National program this morning that Mr Martin Flanagan, author of one of the passages used in the comprehension test from which the minister draws his data, failed 40 per cent of the questions asked in the test about his own piece of writing. Will the minister explain why such a test of comprehension was
so inappropriately used to draw conclusions on literacy? In the light of the latest in a long line of criticisms, will the minister now withdraw his remarks and stop his baseless scare campaign about literacy standards in Australian schools?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —I have had the remarks of Mr Toohey drawn to my attention, although I have not yet had the opportunity to read them completely. When it comes to expertise on educational testing, you, Senator, may choose to go with Mr Toohey and ignore the judgment of the Australian Council for Educational Research. That will be a decision for you. Nonetheless, the Australian Council for Educational Research stands by the validity of its test results. If Mr Toohey had bothered to read the notes on the literacy tests handed out with the minister's press statement, he would understand our test of basic reading comprehension. They do not pretend to be tests of functional literacy.

answer.para: It is possible to compare student performance over time because of the presence of common items. You can give any school a base test to any adult, and they will probably get some of the items wrong. This does not invalidate the test. The basic point—which all Mr Toohey's commentary nonetheless does not obscure—is that since 1975 there has been no basic improvement in basic reading comprehension skills for a significant number of year 9 students and the performance of boys has worsened.

Literacy is too important an issue to be the subject of this sort of political carping, and the schools and the community know it. The government's legislation for the years 1997 to 2000 includes an additional $45 million to help schools with the basic literacy and numeracy needs of students. I presume that is something that you endorse.

talk.start.para:
—I thank the minister for her response. That is precisely the point I wished to make. The minister has made his remarks about a test about comprehension and not about literacy. I also ask for the minister's response to the question on the basis that this test of comprehension is inappropriate, given that there is currently under way a national survey of literacy in Australia. Why did the
minister not wait until that survey was completed before making such remarks?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —I will speak to Dr Kemp. If he has anything to add I will certainly put it in a note and give it to you as soon as I can.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education Training and Youth Affairs.
—Welcome back.

—Thank you. Your spokesperson was quoted in the press last Friday as saying that Austudy was intended `to help the needy and not the greedy' in response to inquiries about cuts in Austudy. Those cuts, your department has confirmed, will mean that 125,000 students across Australia will lose all or part of their Austudy. Does that mean that those 125,000 young Australians are not `needy' and just `greedy'?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —The levels at which people can gain Austudy I do not assume you had planned on changing. I do not assume for one minute that you had planned on increasing the amount that you can earn or have as assets and still get Austudy. In other words, I do not think there is much disagreement amongst either of the major parties and perhaps even the Democrats—although I am not so sure in that respect—about the level at which one ought to be able to gain access to Austudy.

answer.para: Your government, the former government, introduced a means test designed to get at those people who can so structure their affairs as to have a very small taxable income and to hide assets. We support you on that. We think you did the right thing to get at those sorts of people. We are changing the means test in the sense of changing the way we ascertain the means of a person, but not essentially the levels. So, frankly, I do not think there is an argument here.

If the government has set a level at which a benefit can be gained—whether it is Austudy or any other benefit—and someone by, unfortunately, legal means nonetheless seeks a way to get around that and get the
benefits even though in reality they have more, then I think they are greedy. The Commonwealth sets the limits at which benefits can be accessed and people should not try to go around that and get those benefits even if they have income and assets over and above those levels. People who try to do that are greedy. I think that is why you introduced the means test.

question.block.title: Parliament House: Display of Photographs of East Timor

talk.start.para:
—My question is to you, Madam President. I refer to an article in today's
Sydney Morning Herald
indicating that a display of photographs of East Timor, including some of the Dili massacre, has been banned from showing in parliament. If that is so, which of the criteria—and I thank you for a letter today—was used to levy that ban? Was it judged to be `acceptable' or `not acceptable' to the majority of members of parliament or `inconsistent with the dignity of parliament' or `likely to cause offence to a significant part of the Australian community'? If that is the case, would it not be true that banning this display will itself cause offence to a significant part of the Australian community? Would you with your fellow presiding officer send a questionnaire to members of parliament asking whether or not they are prepared to have such a display put up in parliament?
(Time expired)

interject.speaker: PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —I read the article and it seems to be somewhat a figment of somebody's imagination from information I am not quite sure from what source. The situation is that some weeks ago Mr Laurie Ferguson wrote to the Presiding Officers asking for permission, asking for an opportunity, to display some photographs of World War II in relation to that area. That has been agreed to. The time for the exhibition has not yet been agreed. Initially, they wanted it, I think, on 11 November. That was not possible within the structure of exhibitions because there are exhibitions booked in the Presiding Officers' area up until some time in 1998.

interject.para:
Subsequently, I had a telephone call from Senator Reynolds, I think more than two weeks ago now, when she raised the same issue you are now raising of photographs of
Dili—as to whether or not they had been excluded from the exhibition. I told her that there had been no exclusion, that the letter from Mr Ferguson had asked for an exhibition of photographs of World War II. That was approved by the acting Presiding Officers when the Speaker and I were both away. So the question you raised last week when you wrote me a letter about a Dili exhibition is, as I have told you in a letter, a matter that has come up since the last meeting the Presiding Officers had and will be on the agenda for the next meeting.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question as a matter of clarification. In your letter to me today, you have given the outlines of the criteria used for showing exhibitions in the house and in referring to an earlier approach by Mr Ferguson—which included, presumably, contemporary photographs of East Timor, including some of the east Dili massacre—you said, `We believe the exhibition proposed by Mr Ferguson does not fall within this policy.' Can I take this as an indication that the request I have made will find a similar fate. If that is the case, will you send a questionnaire to members so that they might have a say on this very important matter?

—The situation is that Mr Ferguson's request for an exhibition did not mention anything about photographs of the Dili massacre in the first instance. That has been looked at solely within the definition that he put in of World War II photographs. The matter will come up before the Presiding Officers. Your request for a Dili massacre exhibition will come before the Presiding Officers when we next meet. The matter has not yet been dealt with and no further action or decision can be taken by me alone or will be taken until we have an opportunity to look at it.

—My question is to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, can you provide an explanation as to why Australia polled so poorly during the recent ballot for a position on the United Nations Security Council?

—We had a preliminary discussion at the estimates committee on this issue and the advice then was that the government would be carefully considering the circumstances and consequences of the vote to see what lessons could be learnt from the disappointing result.
—You didn't have the numbers.
—That's right, Senator Faulkner. We did not have the numbers. I know you didn't.
—I didn't say that.

—We did not have the numbers. That much we know. The real question is: why did the numbers apparently slip away so dramatically in the days immediately preceding the vote? I do not think that detailed consideration has been completed, but I think part of the answer at least was the fact that Portugal had had only one turn on the Security Council and we had had, as I recall it, four turns. There may well have been a touch of `fair go' in the vote in that regard. Another suggestion—
—Oh, fair go!

—I can understand that argument. Another suggestion is that when it came to the crunch Europe stuck together and, rather than deciding that there should be one European member and one from elsewhere, they decided that if they had the numbers it would be better to have two from Europe. Certainly, it was a disappointing result to us. A lot of work had been done in past years under your government and ours to try to achieve success in that vote. We think we could have made a very useful contribution in the Security Council. It is important that, having lost, we learn from the experience. When that knowledge is to hand, I presume that Mr Downer will be making a statement; if not, I am quite happy to bring his answer back in here for you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I note your comment that maybe the Europeans voted against us, but there has also been speculation that countries in other parts of the world also voted against us, including press
reports that PNG, for example, did not support Australia's bid. Have any reasons been offered then or since as to why that was the case?

—I have seen that press speculation and I will refer that to the foreign minister to see whether he has a comment. All I would say in passing is that, if they did not support us, I would be very disappointed.

—I have a question for the Minister for Communications and the Arts. The Australia-India New Horizons promotion which the minister attended last week was aimed at facilitating closer relations between India and Australia through a series of cultural and trade activities. Can the minister inform the Senate what the cultural program comprised of and how it was received in India?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —A number of major cultural events were organised in accordance with the New Horizons program in India over the last fortnight in a number of leading Indian cities—from New Delhi through to Mumbai, formerly Bombay; Chennai, formerly Madras; Bangalore; and Calcutta.
—You are showing off, Richard.

—What surprised me was that nearly everyone outside Bombay called it Bombay although some of the locals called it Mumbai. I think the same went for Madras. The reception we received was quite interesting because there were some 26 performances given at performing arts venues in five Indian cities and some 15 visual arts performances in six leading Indian cities.
—Were you at the cricket at any stage?
—I am concerning myself with culture. You can define it broadly, if you like.
—So you should.

—I have to confess that I ran into Mark Taylor at our hotel. I asked him whether they were going to win one and he said, `We didn't come here to lose.' He promptly went out and got beaten the next
day. That was about the only sour note because otherwise it was a very successful exercise.

answer.para:
A number of the performers have been asked to return on a commercial basis.
Tap Dogs
was a huge success, and similarly the Australian Arts Orchestra. Circus Oz, as some of you would know, was so successful that it was almost reminiscent of a Collingwood grand final with a number of disappointed punters being turned away. Once again, I think they recognised that Australia had enormous cultural diversity and had a major contribution to make to Indian culture.

talk.start.para: —What about the telephone system?
—I was not asked about the telephone system. If you want to follow that up subsequently, I will be more than happy to tell you. We can draw some very interesting comparisons between Telstra—
—We are waiting to hear. Did you make any calls?
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—There was a very important arts symposium with a number of leading Indian and Australian arts theorists. I have to say that Hilary McPhee's presentation was both thoughtful and erudite.
—Did she say that about you?

—No, I actually introduced her. There was also a launch by Penguin India of three leading Australian writers: David Malouf, Gillian Mears and Libby Hathorn. Once again, I thought that was a very commendable initiative. I hope that Australian writing will be as successfully received in India as it has been in many other countries.
—What were the restaurants like?

—I am fighting fit, thank you. The
Eye of the Storm
, which was a display of Aboriginal art, was very well received. It was organised by the National Gallery in return for the
Vision of Kings
exhibition which came to Australia some 12 months ago.
—Show us the slides.
—Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.

—I am happy to distribute as many mementoes and reminders of the tour as might be relevant to opposition members. But I can assure them that, if they had had the cultural capacity to appreciate what was on display, we could perhaps have invited a few of them to join us. But I did not want to cause a diplomatic incident. I was very sensitive to the fact that the Indians have a high appreciation of Australia's cultural values. Therefore, we unfortunately had to confine the delegation to Australian ministers. There was also a
Fire and Life
exhibition which involved Australian artists and Indian artists working together in a collaborative venture. Once again, that was a very important exercise. Overall, it was a very successful venture.
—It was a comedy show, was it?

—Only back here, I would have thought. But over there I think it was a great milestone in Indian‐Australian relations and a very significant step forward in terms of cultural contacts between our two countries.

question.block.title: Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism

talk.start.para:
—My question is directed to the minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, I refer to your answer to a question without notice last Thursday relating to the ownership by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism of Ralsten Pty Ltd. As it was clear from your answer you did not understand what is at issue here, I ask: are you aware that Ralsten Pty Ltd is a company which trades in shares? Mr Moore did not say, as you asserted he had in your answer, that the company is no longer trading. Are you aware that Mr Moore actually owns this company, even though he has resigned as director and chief operating officer; how can you maintain that ownership of a company which trades in shares does not breach the
Prime Minister's guideline that `Ministers should not operate as traders'?

—According to what I have read in the press, which was an assertion by one of your colleagues in the other place, the articles of association of the company include the capacity to trade in shares. Whether it is actually trading, I do not know—
—It is.
—I will get to that. Whether it is a trader in shares, I do not know.
—What about the next aspect; were you right?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —My answer, as Mike Seccombe pointed out, was incorrect.
—Why didn't you correct it?
—Why don't you let me answer it?
—Senator Faulkner, there is an appropriate time to take notice of answers.

—What Mr Moore had said, which was in the context of the question that was asked, was that he is not a trader. What he did add—well, the question was whether Mr Moore was in breach of the regulations.
—When did you find out your answer was incorrect?
—Order! Senator Forshaw has asked a question that I am sure he wants an answer to. Senators should cease interjecting to allow Senator Hill to answer.
—When did you find out you were wrong?
—Throw him out.
—Senator Faulkner!

—In his statement what he said, which I was recollecting—but now I have had a chance to refresh my memory by re-reading it—was that yes, he did own nine out of the 10 shares but that he had passed control. He said he had nothing to do with the operations of that company. Then, in answer to a subsequent question, I think he read from a letter explaining the passing over of the operational control of the company. He
reiterated that he did not trade, and that is the core of the question.

answer.para: The issue is whether he is in breach of the guidelines. The guidelines provide that ministers shall not trade. He did not trade, nor does he control this particular company. Therefore, he is not in breach of the guidelines. To the extent that my recollection of what he said when he was referring to himself not trading was incorrect, I regret that and apologise to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Firstly, minister, you have just acknowledged that you were incorrect. Could you indicate when you actually ascertained or were informed that your response last week was not correct? Secondly, as the question indicated, Mr Moore is the owner of this company. If, as you say, it is not trading in shares, can you explain why the annual return of the company, lodged with the Australian Securities Commission, specifically stated that the principal activity of the company is that of share trading; and how, therefore, can it be that the owner of the company specifically involved in share trading cannot be involved in trading shares?

—I am sorry, Madam President; I will try to make it clearer. I did not say that the company is not trading in shares. I do not know if it is trading in shares. I acknowledged that I understand, from what your spokesman in the other place said, that the company has within its articles the capacity to trade in shares. It may or it may not. I understood it to be what is described as a diversified investment company—but be that as it may. As to when I was first alerted to the fact that my answer may have been somewhat misleading, it was the assertion made—
—Somewhat?

—Very technical, senator; the assertion made by Mike Seccombe in his article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
.

—My question is also to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to recent comments by
the Minister for Trade, Tim Fischer, that Australia would encourage an improved human rights situation in Burma. I ask: if this is the case, why has Australia already ruled out support for any co‐ordinated economic sanctions against Burma, even though those sanctions have been requested by the Burmese democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and what steps does the government intend to take to help improve the execrable and deteriorating human rights situation in Burma at the moment?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —The continuing trend in Burma is disturbing and, although I notice that NLD deputy, Kyi Maung, has been released, there are still many hundreds of others who are held in political detention in Burma. The laws that have been passed barring Aung San Suu Kyi from holding public meetings are an equally disturbing trend.

answer.para: The issue for countries such as ours—which obviously wants to encourage democracy and better human rights in Burma—is to determine, as you say, what policies might be adopted that could effectively bring that about. This is an issue with which we have been wrestling for a long period of time, and so has the developed world.

The honourable senator will recall that the United States, some years ago, unilaterally introduced certain trade sanctions—as I recall, in relation to textiles. But, because they were unilateral, even though the United States is the most powerful nation on earth, they were ineffective. We have not seen any evidence that there is any suggestion of a broad‐based economic sanction that would have any effect at all.

In fact, unfortunately, much of the unsatisfactory human rights record of the Burmese regime has been built up through the isolation of Burma. There is an argument that, by isolating Burma, all you will do is strengthen the hand of the SLORC. So each of these initiatives has to be examined carefully as to whether they might bring about an effective result.

I do not think that there is any suggestion that our Asian neighbours, particularly in ASEAN, are prepared to go down this path.
I notice that there was a non‐binding resolution of the European Parliament but I do not know of any suggestion that the European governments will join with it. I certainly do not think you will get a mandatory resolution out of the General Assembly. We do hope, however, that there will be a strong resolution passed at the General Assembly which will help demonstrate again the international community's concern about what is happening in that country. But beyond the diplomatic pressures, unfortunately, at the moment, we do not have the magic answer.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for that answer. I am sure that I do not have to remind him of South Africa when I ask my supplementary question. The minister mentioned in his answer that the world—and the developed world—has been wrestling for a long period of time with this question, and I agree with that. But I ask the minister to go to the foreign minister and bring back to the Senate whether the following two responses are being considered by Australia. The first is to close the Austrade office in Rangoon. Considering how many officers of Austrade are being retrenched, I think that closing the Austrade office in Rangoon would be a very good move. The second is agreeing to restrict the provision of visas for family members of the SLORC, which, I understand, is also being considered by other countries.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —I will refer those matters back. The Austrade office, as I recall, has only one or two locally engaged personnel in it. It is not an overly active office. I suspect that the only consequence of that would be to throw one or two Burmese onto the unemployment heap. But I will ask the Minister for Trade when he returns whether he thinks there would be any political pressure that would result as a consequence of throwing a couple of Burmese out of work.

answer.para:
In relation to the visa issue, I will also refer that to the relevant minister. I cannot remember the last time the SLORC visited Australia. There was a visit to Perth some years ago by an official. I do not think we are on the SLORC's regular visiting list. I doubt very much whether that would be effective. But I
will ask the relevant minister whether he has anything to add to that.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to Commonwealth initiatives to establish a uniform defamation code across Australia. What are the implications of this proposal for publication on the Internet? Is it the government's intention to extend common law libel protection to Internet publications? What advice, if any, has the Commonwealth received on the jurisdictional issues involved in such a proposal?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —I do not think I have advice on that particular aspect at the moment. But, given your usual charming self, I will go to great lengths to get an answer for you as quickly as I possibly can.
—I could not possibly ask a supplementary question after that.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, you would be aware that reductions in interest rates, following the budget, have pushed housing affordability to record levels. What implications does this have for the reform of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Tierney for his question because it is an important issue for all Australians. Senator Kemp has already at question time today made clear the government's satisfaction at the improvement in housing affordability, because it is a vindication of our budget strategy and the need for a competitive banking sector.

answer.para:
Housing affordability is now at a two-year high. In some cities the index is the highest that it has ever been and, of course, that is welcome news for home buyers. But home buyers are not the only beneficiaries, Senator Tierney; low income renters are also going to be beneficiaries of it. Of the 1.2 million low income renters in Australia, over 900,000 are in the private sector. For them, the level of housing affordability is going to have a
bearing both on their rent and on the availability of housing for them.

One of the concerns which are motivating reform of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement is that we need to involve the private sector more in the provision of low cost housing. The public sector is just not doing its job. For example, in 1988-89 the various state housing authorities built 14,000 new homes but by 1995 that number was down to 5,000, despite the fact that funding levels had not changed. If nothing changes in coming years, no new homes will be built and the Commonwealth's funding will just be chewed up in maintenance and administration, as has increasingly been happening over the last few years.

The solution is to involve the private sector more, both in the capital funding of public housing and in the provision in the private sector. Lower interest rates can help that process—something which the Housing Industry Association, I am glad to see, has also recognised. If we can get more landlords providing cheaper accommodation to low income renters and also providing greater rental assistance to low income people, we can alleviate one of the great causes of poverty in this country—excessive housing costs. To keep housing costs down and to encourage this process, it is vital that the government's budget comes through this chamber intact. Every extra cent taken from the public purse puts pressure on interest rates. It would be a terrible shame if this did not happen because cheaper housing for both home buyers and renters would go a long way to relieving poverty for the long term.

From the chattering classes on the opposite side of the chamber, it is clear that, despite their time in government, they have not recognised that the Social Security Department's research makes it very clear that the people who are receiving rent assistance through the Department of Social Security, who are on low incomes, are renting right across the geographical areas of Australian cities and towns, and right across the rental levels. In other words, people are sometimes sacrificing their standard of living in order to be able to afford a standard of housing.

break.para: That has been the choice for a number of years of people renting in the private market, even though they are on low income. We say that that is right and proper, that they have that choice. But at the moment there is an inadequate rent assistance for those people. What we want to do is make sure that there are sufficient people investing in the private system and that there be quality accommodation for low income earners to rent.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be put on notice.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Childs today, relating to the funding of government schools.

This Senate has heard a number of boneheaded answers from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), but this would surely have to be one of the most boneheaded of all. What we heard here today was a proposition that she read out from the propaganda statements of the minister for schools. She was then asked by way of a simple question to contrast those statements with the statements made by her own officials to the estimates committee—

Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Just a moment. There are too many interjections in the chamber. Would senators please take their seats or leave the chamber.

—We had a very simple case where the minister was called upon to read out the propaganda statements of her junior minister. She was confronted with the obvious contradictions of statements which are, of course, in contrast with the statements made by her own officials. At the estimates committee, in answer to questions from me, there was a situation whereby, instead of the $1.5 billion worth of extra funding that they are claiming, according to their own officials the figure is only $128 million over a four‐year period.

break.para: The minister was asked to explain this. She simply cannot, because what she has engaged in is a whole issue of myth making. It is not about fact; it is not about understanding. It is about myth making. It is about spreading propaganda porkies in such a way as to present to the public a position which is in quite sharp contrast to the facts.

The budget estimates in particular seem to be most flexible. We have seen a situation where, within a two‐month period, this government has presented to the Senate a figure for the cost of its new schools policy, which has then changed, in terms of a submission presented to the Senate legislation committee last Friday—an increase of some $50 million dollars within a period of only two months.

It is quite an extraordinary flexibility. Last Friday we saw this exercise in myth‐making taken a step further with Minister Kemp indicating that he was seeking to pre‐empt the states grants bill inquiry by the Senate legislation committee with a claim that this government was seeking to increase expenditure for school education by $1.5 billion. Nothing could be further from the truth in terms of the statements already given to this parliament through the budget process.

The reality of this story is simple: such an attempt to repackage this budget will, of course, fail because it is predicated on a total myth. That myth is very simply this: rather than increasing money for schools, particularly for public education, this budget is about reducing money for public education. What we see is that this figure of $177 million in tied grants has been taken from government schools while there is, in fact, an increase in the non‐government school sector of $150 million.

Now, of course, what these calculations are based upon is that undermining, false claim that somehow or other we can add together the monies provided by the commonwealth to the states for financial assistance grants—the FAGs. We can add together special purpose grants and then we can divide by the number of students in this country and then somehow you get an improved number for spending on schools overall. And, of course, the minister
has failed to take away from his calculations the $1.5 billion that this Commonwealth government has already deducted from the states at the June premiers' conference.

It is abundantly clear what these lies are. Instead, around 24 per cent of FAGs actually end up being spent on government schools, but only two per cent will be spent on non‐government schools. Now, of course, it is wrong to rely upon those states like Victoria, which has set out over the last four years to undermine the public education system. To rely upon those same states to replace the moneys that the Commonwealth is taking out of the education system, of course, is to fly in the face of all reality.

Now, Minister Vanstone has sought to repeat these myths in such a way as to try to give the impression that this government is actually spending money—which it is not. Under their new, proposed, deregulated schools policy, the enrolment adjustment benchmarking program that they have undertaken will see $177 million actually taken away from the public sector. And, of course, rather than working with the states as this minister states, governments—such as those of Queensland, Western Australia and New South Wales—have all categorically condemned this government for its unilateral action in undermining public education and from taking money away from the states rather than adding money to it.

So we are talking about cost shifting, as this minister did today. What we see is a situation where the Commonwealth is seeking to shift costs to the states in such a manner as to fundamentally undermine the public education system. For the first time in the history of this country, the Commonwealth government is actually turning its back on its obligations to public education and the children of this country.

speech.speaker: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

talk.start.para:
—I rise to support my colleague, Senator Carr, in this motion to take note of Senator Vanstone's answers and to join him in criticism of Minister Vanstone and the response she has given. In particular, it a criticism of her but also, more importantly, a criticism of this government which promised
everything—everything—to the people of Australia before March and we have seen since the budget the way in which they have delivered. They have delivered in this area the most amazing set of cuts and, as Senator Carr as already said, in a total policy vacuum. There is no sense at all from the opposition of what their schools policy is about. There is no sense at all—
—Rubbish!

—It is very good that you say `rubbish', Senator Tierney. What I would like to know is whether Senator Tierney says `rubbish' because he is backing what Senator Vanstone first said or what Senator Vanstone says when she comes in here to correct what she first said. And so far Senator Vanstone has had three, four, five attempts to correct what she has already said. This is a minister who gets her facts and advice very wrong, who misleads this Senate with great regularity and who actually is misleading the people of Australia with the most remarkable explanations of policy, education and, in particular, her commitment to schools.

speech.para: It is interesting that there is no consistency from the government at all in what they are doing here. They have actually indicated in many cases that they would rather pass the money to the states to allow the states to manage but, in this case, they have rejected the commission of audit. They are going to manage it better from the commonwealth side because that is the way they can actually reject support for the public schools system and move the money to the private school system. They are actually shifting considerable money out of the public education system and it is completely contradictory—

talk.start.para: —Why do you hate private schools?

—You have just heard the figures given by Senator Carr: take note of them because, already, Liberal state governments are objecting strenuously to what this federal government is doing to funding for schools in the states. That is a matter of the greatest concern because we have an absolute policy vacuum and, if I was kinder, I would say instead of no policy at all, a
complete contradiction of policy in this area. On the one hand, we want to support literacy for our children and, on the other, we are taking away the funding for the public schools that might allow and assist that. It is completely contradictory and it is very, very damaging that we would have a federal government that says one thing and delivers another. It says it is committed to public schools; it says it is committed to continuing school funding but, as Senator Carr points out, indeed it has not done so. It has dramatically reduced funding to the public school system and, as he said, to the point where our state education ministers—Liberals—are protesting rigorously at what this government is doing to state education in their states, but it is across the board. And it is—there is no doubt and it is very clear—a shift of money away from our public schools to private schools.

speech.para: That is what it is about. Nothing more or less. It is all done in the name of increased choice. Choice is a good thing and, of course, the Labor Party would support that and, indeed, introduced a lot of those policies but the way the government is using this word is an abuse of it.

talk.start.para: —They have taken the choice away from others.
—Exactly so! It is to reduce the choice and to just use the word whenever you want to make a decision that is going to move money from one sector to another.

speech.para: There is no choice for people in the public sector, for people using public schooling, if their funding is being dramatically reduced. Their choices are being reduced; their educational access and educational opportunities are being reduced.

Government members interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Government members, who have polished personal abuse to an art form, have again just committed the same gross error. Funding has been dramatically reduced. I think it is an insult to ordinary intelligence to say to people that they have more choice when funding is being dramatically restricted.

break.para: Minister Vanstone is assisted by Dr Kemp, but she is the minister responsible in this area. On a number of occasions she has misled the Senate and Senate estimates committees and has then come back to correct her information. It is becoming more and more clear that we have a minister who we are unable to rely on. Sadly, the people of Australia cannot rely on her for public education.

speech.speaker: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

talk.start.para: —Last Friday the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, David Kemp, announced an unbelievable proposition to Australia; that was, that this government had actually increased funding to the government school area. That reminded me of the events that occurred in the televised world series wrestling. In this case, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, was on the ropes and ready to go down for the third of the best of three falls. Minister Kemp has jumped into the ring to try to save her from that third fall. This is an unbelievable proposition.

speech.para: As we have just heard from Senator Carr, when the budget was announced cuts to the government school sector totalled $128 million; they are now almost $177 million. That is according to the most recent answers that we have been given by Minister Vanstone and her departmental staff in relation to the impact of the abolition of the new schools policy and the application of the enrolment benchmark measure to the funding of the schools sector in Australia.

There clearly is a case of cost shifting to the states in this area, and a big question mark hangs over what is going to happen to the funding of both the government and the non‐government school sectors arising from this policy. The minister and departmental staff have consistently said that what happens with the funding of schools in the states is going to be left to the states, that they are going to be freed up to make their decisions. When you look at the regulation of the non-government schools that applies in the various states, it is pretty clear that they have relied upon the Labor new schools policy as a de facto means of regulating the education sector. There is no doubt it is on the public
record and that there are very few tests in relation to the viability of schools, to the establishment of schools which directly compete with other funded educational entities in the same sector, other than Labor's new schools policy.

Labor had announced and established a review of that policy to finetune it. This government is simply saying, `We will sweep all of this away and, as we do so, we are going to make some massive changes to the funding of the sector.' We have been told that we will now see at least $177 million go from the state sector. We have been told that the non‐government sector will get an additional $150 million from the enrolment benchmark measure. But if that figure is as rubbery as the figure that relates to the reduction in funding in the government sector, perhaps we can expect that there will be an even greater increase in funding to the non-government sector.
None of the private school areas are able to give us any real estimate of the effect of these measures in terms of the additional funds they will be receiving from the Commonwealth. Some would have us believe that there will be a small impact. Some would have us believe that there will be no impact at all, which makes a deception of the figures announced by this government. There are others who say that the impact of this measure will be to greatly increase the funding of the non-government sector and to reduce the funding of the government sector, perhaps to the effect of doubling the funding of the non-government sector and reducing the funding of the government sector by as much as 20 per cent over a five‐ to 10‐year period. So we have had a variety of answers on this question.

The answers that the minister has given today and earlier are demonstrative of the fact that even the minister does not know just how much of an impact these measures are going to have. Nor does her department and, from the evidence we have had, nor does the private school sector. It is a disgraceful policy approach by this government, an approach that can only destabilise the government education sector.

break.para: The minister ought to have a closer look at the figures and this government ought to reconsider its policies and decide to make some real impact on the government sector in this country, because we can see—and all my constituents are telling me—that it is about time some stability were introduced into the government sector, and this policy is not going to achieve that. It is going to destabilise it; it is going to destroy schools. It will see the educational opportunities for 70 per cent of Australians reduced on the basis of choice, a choice which is going to be exercised against the interests of the majority.

speech.speaker: Tierney, Sen John

talk.start.para: —I was not going to rise and speak in this debate, but I cannot let the nonsense we have heard from the preceding three speakers just lie. What we are talking about here is the balance between the funding for private schools and state schools. The most sensible thing previous speakers mentioned was choice, and that is really what this is all about.

speech.para: We do live in a liberal democracy. We do have choices in all areas of life. There is public and private provision in many areas of life. Listening to the evidence in the hearings we are having on the schools bill, one would think that there should not be any choice, that parents do not have a right to spend their own money on sending their children to private schools. It is as though we were back in the old Russia or the old eastern Europe. For some reason people think it is a terrible thing that parents are putting in money for their children's private school education and that the state should in some way support that.

A lot of myths have flown around in this debate today and a lot flew around during the hearing. The biggest myth of all is that in some way it is the people in the public schools that are supporting those in the private schools.

I put to the Senate that if we did have a totally public education system and no private education system, which some of these people opposite seem to want, we would have to find $1½ billion extra to support the schooling system. Where would it come from? It would not come from the roads and the hospitals and
social welfare. It would come from the other schools. So the provision of education across the country would be at a lower level if that occurred.

In this country, by rough measure, two‐thirds of the children go to public schools and one‐third go to private schools. There are natural barriers to increasing that number—something which people opposite do not seem to understand. Even though it has been stated in surveys that 95 per cent of parents would like to send their child to a private school, obviously they are not going to do it because of the cost.

So the figure for private schools is one‐third—not even up to one‐third. As a matter of fact, with the schools policy that we have now introduced, on estimates that figure is going to move up about 1½ per cent over the next four years. A dramatic change is not going to occur in the balance between private and public schools, but this new policy will give parents who want to send their children to a private school the opportunity to do that.

We have heard in the debate today, and also in the hearings, that there is a cost shift between the two sectors. For some reason, the opposition feel that state schools are going to be disadvantaged and private schools advantaged. People get up here and say the state schools are being disadvantaged. In reality they are left with the money even though the pupil has left. What is the disadvantage in that? We have had quite a number of people outside the parliament spreading propaganda on this matter. The head of the Teachers Federation had her name on a document which has gone around a whole series of schools and spread a whole series of untruths about this.

In reality, we in this government have created a proper schools policy which does give parents real choice and does not put handicaps on and create barriers for parents
to be able to set up a different sort of education that they want. Such barriers did exist under the previous Labor government. They do not exist under this new policy. Parents do have a choice. This is a democracy. They do have that right.

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para: —I have listened to the debate so far, and the proposal being put by Senator Carr and Senator O'Brien was not that one school sector should be starved because of another, but that adequate schooling should be provided for all. That seems to me to be a fair proposition.

speech.para: Senator Carr comes from the state of Victoria. He has often spoken to me about his concern for education across the board in that area. You, Mr Deputy President, would know the very great need there is for adequate schooling for all people, no matter where they come from. Senator Carr has pointed out to me—and it is correct to my knowledge—that in the state of Victoria 300 schools have been closed since 1992. That is right, isn't it, Senator Carr?

talk.start.para: —That is right.

—And 8,000 teachers have gone. With them has gone an incredible amount of knowledge, skill and learning. That is what we are on about. I heard a news item or program on the radio recently where they said that by the year 2000 there will be a shortage of teachers. Is that right, Senator Carr?
—That is right again.

—That is a shortage of teachers right across the board. To try to say that we on this side of the house are sowing division between the state system and the private system is really to throw up a smokescreen where there certainly should not be a smokescreen thrown. This is a matter of a very serious nature.

speech.para:
When people talk about choice what do they mean by that? Is there a real choice there? An article in one of the Melbourne papers the other day spoke of a family that was shifting out to Balwyn to try to get into the North Balwyn state school. That is a school with a high reputation in that area. The
people had sold their house and shifted to North Balwyn in an attempt to get their child—there was one child as I remember it—into the North Balwyn state school.

talk.start.para: —That does happen.

—As Senator Panizza says, that does happen. When we talk about choice, what choice is there for people who are unable to go to live in North Balwyn? No matter where you are in Melbourne, people say North Balwyn is an outstanding school. But it can only take a certain number of people and, with other schools closed, where are children who miss out on schools like North Balwyn to go?

speech.para: The same sort of thing occurs at secondary level, not just at primary level. There is jockeying for an opportunity to go to Melbourne High School, University High School and MacRobertson Girls School. They are within the state system. Even within that system there is not the choice available to the students that there ought to be. That is what we on this side of the chamber are talking about. That is what Senator Carr is on about, not choice between one system and another but a proper choice within each system and across both systems so that everybody, no matter whether they come from Glenroy or Balwyn, has an opportunity to get the sort of education everybody is entitled to.

Of course we are on about choice. That is what we are on about everywhere but we want a real choice; and you do not get a real choice unless all schools are of such a quality that they can stand up against each other. Until we get that quality in all schools we are in trouble. It is not about competition; it is about giving everybody the opportunity. Once everybody has an opportunity, people have choice.

speech.speaker: Forshaw, Sen Michael

talk.start.para:
—I rise on the same matter. I have to say that in about the last hour or so I have heard two contributions, firstly from the minister and subsequently from Senator Tierney, which I would have to describe not only as bone‐headed—as Senator Carr put it so well—but as quite disgraceful and divisive contributions on the issue of school education. During the contribution by Senator Tierney,
who unfortunately has left the chamber, I thought for a moment we were heading back to the 1960s, that we were getting back to that era when there was an acrimonious, sectarian debate in the community regarding the merits of private versus public sector education. I believe that we as a country and as political parties have developed a lot further since then and that, indeed, there was a recognition on the part of all political parties that the education system in this country is based upon the existence of a state school system, government funded—
—Comprehensive.

—Yes, together with the existence of a private sector system of education—in the main the Catholic school system but also with the existence of a range of other private schools. I also thought there was a recognition that government accepted a responsibility to contribute to the maintenance of both those systems and to ensure equity and quality within both those systems. Yet Senator Tierney started talking about Russia, as if people on this side were harking back to the old days of saying that there should be no private school education in this country. speech.para:
Labor has always followed a policy of ensuring that adequate funding is available. You have only to look at our record. The fact that high school retention rates doubled in the years we were in government from 1983 to 1996 is proof of that. We raised by 100 per cent the standard in terms of people staying at high school. What we now have is a policy which harks back to the old approach of
liberal governments in the past; that is, education directed at ensuring that the wealthy get the best end of the deal.
