break.para: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996
The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 contains non-Budget amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 (the Social Security Act).

Subject to agreement by the opposition parties, this bill could be dealt with as a non-controversial bill to be passed in the current sittings period. The measures in this bill and the benefits of securing its early passage are explained below.

Schedule 1 makes payments of financial assistance from the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust to persons with medically acquired HIV infection and AIDS (and payments to the dependants and carers of such persons) exempt assets for the purposes of the assets test consistent with an undertaking given by a former Minister for Social Security, the Hon Peter Baldwin. Such payments are already exempt income for the purposes of the income test. Since the Schedule 1 amendments commence on the date of Royal Assent, an earlier passage of the legislation would financially benefit persons for whom it is often critical to receive financial assistance as early as possible.

Schedule 2 allows the continuation of automatic transfer of mature age partner allowees to wife pension when their mature age allowance partners transfer to age pension after 30 June 1995. Mature age partner allowees in that situation lost access to wife pension as an unintended consequence of the decision to phase out wife pension from 1 July 1995. Currently, they are paid an equivalent to wife pension by way of ex-gratia payments. These amendments commence on the date of Royal Assent. An earlier passage of the legislation would provide earlier legislative authority for payment of wife pensions to the affected women that would remove the necessity of relying in this respect on ex-gratia payments.

Schedule 3 contains two measures. The first measure corrects a technical fault in the Method Statement in point 1210-A1 of the Social Security Act to ensure that the Method statement provides a mechanism for the correct calculation of a `notional family payment rate'. The second measure amends saving provisions in clause 54 of Schedule 1A of the Social Security Act to continue the effect of this clause and so ensure that the results of the application of the Method Statement are correct. Customers affected by the operation of this clause are currently being paid correct amounts from funds advanced for that purpose by the Minister for Finance for the period that ends on 1 January 1997. The amendments made by the second measure commence on the day of Royal Assent. An earlier passage of the legislation would provide earlier
legislative authority for the payment of correct amounts to affected customers.

Schedule 4 corrects an unintended error made by the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Act 1992 to Pension Rate Calculator A in the Social Security Act. This will ensure that the pre-1 January 1993 position for the treatment of reduction of ordinary income of a person who is a member of a couple and whose partner is receiving a social security or service pension, is re-instated.
This statement is circulated with the authority of the Minister for Social Security, Senator the Hon Jocelyn Newman
CFM SALE BILL 1996
Purpose of the bill

1.
The purpose of the bill is to provide for the disposal of Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM) and/or its business or wholly owned subsidiaries such as Total Risk Management Pty Limited by way of trade sale, management buyout or other appropriate process. The significant matters proposed for inclusion in the bill will:

1.
remove legislative constraints on sale and enable the constraints on sale in CFM's Memorandum and Articles of Association to be removed;

2.
provide for the Minister for Finance to declare a specified day(s) as the sale day(s),

3.
provide for Regulations to be able to be made and for these to be able to have a date of effect other than the date of Gazettal;

4.
cease the Australian Public Service mobility rights of employees of CFM from sale day,

5.
provide that existing Commonwealth legislation applying to CFM because of its status as a Commonwealth-owned entity will not apply to CFM from sale day and that post-sale, CFM is, as far as practicable, not subject to Commonwealth legislation which does not also govern the activities of (other private sector companies;

6.
provide for transitional and savings provisions in relation to a range of pre‐sale rights or obligations. The principal areas involve obligations in relation to employees and some administrative and legal issues;

7.
make any necessary consequential amendments to other Commonwealth Acts and Regulations; and

8.
amend or repeal certain parts of the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Act 1990.
Reasons for seeking introduction and passage in the one Sitting

1.
Both introduction and passage in the Spring Sittings are sought to enable the early removal of the legislative constraint on sale of CFM:

1.
so as to enable the uncertainties that that constraint places on CFM's future, including its business and staff, to be resolved as soon as possible;

2.
so that in the conduct of the scoping study, potential purchasers will not be discouraged from expressing an interest in purchase of CFM by the uncertainty of its availability for sale; and

3.
depending on the results of the scoping study, to enable any subsequent formal sale process to be undertaken without delay:

para.tab:
.
thus ensuring that any potential disruption to clients and staff of CFM is kept to a minimum; and

.
to avoid the expressed interest of purchasers from being dissipated with a potential consequential reduction in the price that might be realised.

proctext.para: That the following matter be referred to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report:
The necessity for public accountability of all government services provided by government contractors, including:

(a)
how best to ensure that the rights, interests and responsibilities of consumers, contracted service providers and government agencies can be defined and protected, with particular reference to:

para.tab:
(i)
whether contracting out arrangements should be governed by written contracts between the government agency and the service provider in all cases,

(ii)
whether contracts should contain standard clauses dealing with matters such as responsibility for record keeping, complaints and dispute resolution procedures, and the allocation of responsibility between the contracting agency and the contractor in the event of financial or other loss on the part of the consumer, and

definition of standards of service;

proctext.para:
(b)

(c)

Ombudsman's Act 1976

whether government, to meet its responsibilities for policy making, should have access to all files, information etc. generated by private‐sector contractors in meeting their contractual obligations; and

talk.start.para: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 293, relating to the beatification of Edmund Rice, be taken as formal.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a brief statement before this motion is declared formal.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. When I saw the wording of Senator Cooney's notice of motion No. 293, I felt a level of concern and discomfort. The reason for that is that it is in three parts: it notes the beatification of Edmund Rice as the founder of the Christian Brothers in Ireland—and that is obviously a statement of a matter of fact; it remembers the coming to Australia of the Christian Brothers and says that from that time `they have given unceasing service to education initiative this country. . . '; and in part (c) it expresses its appreciation of the dedication of the Christian Brothers in Australia and says that it hopes they will go on to serve the community well in the years ahead.

speech.para: My concern is that there is an ongoing level of community concern as well about the incidents that have occurred, certainly in the past, in relation to children in the charge of Christian Brothers in schools and in other establishments. I certainly acknowledge that there are a great many people in Australia who owe their entire education to the Christian Brothers. I am quite happy to acknowledge that there are many people who are very grateful for that.

I will not be opposing the formality of this motion, but I will be voting against the motion. I think it is reasonable, if the majority of the Senate wish to vote for it, for me not to stand in the way of that and not to force a full debate. I contacted the group called Voices in Western Australia to see if my concerns were founded and I read through the wording of the motion.

I asked whether or not those people who were still struggling for recognition of their concerns by the church would feel hurt if everyone in the Senate approved the wording
of this motion. They indicated that they would. In some ways, there are some parallels in relation to `the stolen generation'; the very first thing that must happen before real healing can occur is that there is proper recognition. If nothing else within my time in the Senate, I want to provide some voice for the voiceless, as that is necessary. As I say, it is not a comment on the general nature of Christian Brothers education, but it is a statement for those people who are still struggling for recognition and have not yet got the recognition or the acceptance of liability that I believe they deserve.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I want to acknowledge the very honourable way in which Senator Cooney has promoted this motion and accommodated my approaches to find wording which would allow Senate unanimity. But while recognising the dedication of so many Christian Brothers over so many years, I must also endorse the stand that Senator Margetts has made; for in acknowledging past disgrace and hurt as well as the grace and care rests our best chance to build a better, safer future for everyone.

speech.speaker: Woodley, Sen John

talk.start.para: —by leave—The Democrats would not object to formality for this motion because I would endorse what has already been said about the Catholic education system and the part that Christian Brothers have played in that. Indeed, at times I have taught in Catholic schools and I have grandchildren who have attended them. The benefit they have received is undoubted.

speech.para:
However, there are people who feel that, because of the current controversy surrounding some members of the Christian Brothers, they have some problems with this.
I simply put that on the record, indicate that the Democrats will certainly support formality for this motion and commend Senator Cooney for bringing it here, but particularly for the way in which he brought it. I indicate that we trust that given the good will that is certainly amongst all the churches surrounding the issues which are of controversy at the moment, we may be able to sort out in the future
some of the damage which has been done, as well as the good work.

speech.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment)

talk.start.para: —by leave—Mr Deputy President—
—We are not going to debate this, are we?

—No. The problem, Senator, is that in some ways, by seeking to make a statement to justify her vote, Senator Margetts has not only introduced a debate but unfortunately somewhat tainted the resolution that will pass. I want to make it clear that from the government's perspective the motion should be strongly supported. I commend Senator Cooney for bringing it. It is wrong, I believe, to in any way colour the order with the misbehaviour of a few. I think that today is an occasion to recognise the enormous work that the order and the spirit of its founder have done for the benefit of—speaking of Australia only—hundreds of thousands of children over the years and to recognise it with appreciation.

speech.para: As a non‐Catholic, I did not know perhaps as much as I should have about Edmund Rice until I attended a very large mass last Friday in Adelaide as part of the beatification ceremonies. Clearly, he was a man who dedicated his life to those who were poor, to those who were uneducated, and set an example that has been followed by many after him, in terms of helping and supporting young people throughout the world with education, accommodation and in other ways to help give them a good start in the world.

In supporting this motion, I say on behalf of the government that we clearly do express our appreciation for the dedication of the Christian Brothers in Australia. We look forward to the good works that the Christian Brothers will continue to do for the benefit of those who are not so well off in our community in the years ahead.

talk.start.para: —There being no objection to formality, I call Senator Cooney.

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para:
—by leave—I thank all the senators who have spoken and cooperated in this. I should
mention Senator Panizza, who has done much in getting this motion up, and my own whip, Senator Chris Evans, who, in his usual style, has done great work. Having said that, I move:

speech.para: That the Senate—

(a)
notes the beatification in Rome on 6 October 1996 of Edmund Rice, the founder in 1802 of the Christian Brothers in Ireland;

(b)
remembers the coming to Australia of the Christian Brothers, at first in 1843 for a period of four years, and then in 1868 from which time they have given this country generous and unceasing service; and

(c)
expresses its appreciation of the dedication of the Christian Brothers in Australia and hopes that they will go on to serve the community well in the years ahead.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 310, standing in my name for today, relating to an order for the production of documents, be taken as a formal motion. I indicate that I will be asking for general business notice of motion No. 313, standing in my name for today, relating to reconvening of the estimates committee process, to be taken as a formal motion as well, after this one is completed.
—We will deal with No. 310 first. Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?

speech.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment)

talk.start.para:
—by leave—I want to make a few comments on notices of motion Nos 310 and 313, which relate to similar matters. We strongly oppose the motions. This process of a return to order by the Senate in the event of anything that is politically controversial has become something of a farce. Practically not a day goes by without the opposition coming in here and attempting to tie up the administration of government in this country by a spurious return to order. We did not adopt this practice. Occasionally, when there was a serious matter to which this mechanism was appropriate, that is, requiring documents pursuant to an order to be tabled, we utilised the process.
But you have just turned it into a matter of form. On any political excursion that you enter upon now, part of the process is to come in here and, with the numbers that you seem to inevitably have, pass a resolution.
—I wish it was true.

—We get used to working as a minority in this place, but we will battle on. You pass a resolution with little purpose other than to clog up the business of government, and that is what you are seeking here again. You are seeking documents from me on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), documents from the Minister for Justice (Mr Williams) and documents from the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull)—all records. You have not even sought to specify the records that you want. Presumably you are arguing that there was some sort of irregularity in relation to this tendering process.

speech.para: I would have thought you would have at least shown some effort by seeking to identify the documents that you want. But no, you are not interested in that. It is simply `all documents', which therefore demonstrates that this is purely a fishing exercise. Why you did not go down the usual path of seeking these documents through the estimates committee and debating it at the estimates committee, I do not know. That is what normal Senate procedure would have warranted. But instead you complete your task in the estimates committee, then you come back here and you require the production of all documents that are imaginable—all documents, whether they are legal advices, commercial-in-confidence or whatever. There is no effort to distinguish those that it would be improper for us to table.

In other words, you want a resolution of the Senate today that you know we will not be able to comply with if we are to maintain longstanding practices. I can assure the opposition that, even if they have the numbers on this, we will be sticking by the previous accepted rules. I have already indicated to Senator Bolkus that we would be prepared to provide certain documents in confidence that relate to the tendering process, in confidence because they are the commercial documents of those who tendered. But that process,
apparently, is unsuccessful. You rather want to pursue the fishing exercise and then to make your decisions afterwards.

Legal documents, cabinet documents, commercial-in‐confidence, you know and I know we cannot comply with. Why you have sought to impose upon us an order that you know we cannot comply with I cannot answer, except that you are simply up to mischief. We will therefore oppose this motion today, as we will presumably address the one we will get tomorrow and the day after and the day after. It has become your usual practice.

speech.speaker: Bolkus, Sen Nick

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a few comments for about the same time as Senator Hill, which is five minutes.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —By way of explanation, we are seeking documents here. We have not taken this position lightly. It is a critical issue that we are talking about here. We are talking about the implementation of the gun buy-back scheme. We are talking about the application of money raised from the taxpayer to ensure that the scheme is implemented properly and extensively.

speech.para: If we had taken the approach that Senator Hill suggests that we were taking, that approach being of frustration, then we could have very easily moved the process of suspending standing orders and embarking upon a debate. It was I who offered to Senator Hill a fast‐track proposal for this, one that he was very keen to pursue. In terms of our discussion I acknowledge that where things are commercial-in-confidence there will be a fair degree of acceptance of those documents having their commercial-in-confidence aspects.

para.break: So Senator Hill, we are not being destructive or frustrating you here. What we are saying is that there are some important documents, some important issues, some important information that needs to be seen by the public and by the Senate. For instance, during the estimates process the opposition tackled these issues through both the finance and public administration and legal and constitu tional affairs legislation committees. We are awaiting further information that we have not got through that process.

speech.para: One of the reasons that we want to pursue the reopening of this committee in the same way as the other committee is being reopened is to ensure that the information that we are given can be tested. You cannot test one side of the argument without testing the other. The government has accepted that they will reconvene the finance and public administration estimates process. It is important to reconvene this one as well. We are talking here about the agency that purchased the contract—Attorney-General's. They are the agency with responsibility for the funding, for spending the funding and for running the campaign.

Since the last estimates hearings, some three weeks ago, we have seen corrections by the government of evidence provided at that estimates proceeding by Mr Smeaton and by Senator Kemp, correcting a very critical piece of information as to whether Mr Morris's intervention ensured the listing of DDB Needham on the short list, on the list to be considered, or whether that had already taken place beforehand. In the estimates process we were told that Mr Morris's intervention had nothing do with the company being listed. Senator Kemp had to come in here and embarrassingly apologise for the fact that the evidence was wrong and that it was Mr Morris's letter which ensured that this company, this tender, got into the ballpark.

There are inconsistencies between AG's and DAS in the information provided to us. So we need to clear it up at both ends. We need to clear up a whole range of questions that have been left unanswered. For instance, we know that three documents of advice have gone to the government in respect of DDB Needham. Elliott and Shanahan declared it to be a pretty poor tender and claimed that in no sense of the word was it up to scratch. OGIA, the government information agency, also advised the government that it should steer clear of and not touch DDB Needham with a barge pole.

para.break: The one document we do not have is the advice from the Attorney-General's Depart ment to the Attorney-General (Mr Williams). We need to get that to address questions such as: why did the Attorney-General not take a position on this particular campaign when it was so critical to the implementation of the government's buy-back program? We need to find out on whose advice the focus of the campaign was changed. There is a whole range of issues that need to be addressed—issues of inconsistency and issues which go to tackling parts of the problem and not just concentrating on the perspective of the finance and government operation, Department of Administrative Services.

speech.para: The campaign has not started and it is five weeks late already. The campaign was supposed to start in October this year. We have not as yet seen the creative work. We do not know, and we should know by now, to what extent integration with the states—a critical part of the campaign—has proceeded. All these issues need to be addressed and this is why we have moved for a re-opening of the estimates process in the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in the same way that the process has been reopened in the finance and public administration committee. As I have said, documents are critical. We are not being `frustrative'; we are being constructive, and to that extent we are taking this approach with the government. Otherwise, Senator Hill, you know quite well we could be here all afternoon dragging this out, and that is not what we want to do.

speech.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment)

talk.start.para: —by leave—This is the second half of this attempt to frustrate the government's program by recalling this committee unnecessarily—a committee that had finished its business for this session—in the hope that something might be dragged out of it that could be politically damaging in some way.

speech.para: If there was any case for this, if there was an argument that something had been missed before or at the last hearing, then it might be a different matter, but no attempt has been made to develop a case for it other than that the opposition wants another go at it. In other words, it wants to drag the committee members out, and all the public servants, to run through it again just in case the opposition had forgotten a question on the last occasion and out of that fishing trip it might gain something for which it thinks it can get some political mileage. This turns the process into a farce, I would suggest. For that reason, this should be opposed.

There was another question asked at the administrative services committee that dealt with the same matter and an answer was given that was subsequently found to be incorrect. When that came to our attention and the opposition wanted to re-open the inquiry to pursue matters arising out of the incorrect answer, our response was that it was
proper for them to do so and we agreed, without having to come in here and fight the numbers, to that committee being re-opened to explore that matter. That did not seem to us to be unreasonable. A mistake had been made; it had been corrected, but nevertheless that does in our view give the opposition a legitimate opportunity to come back and say it wants to explore the consequences of the now correct answer.

But that does not apply to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. There has been no suggestion that any answer that was given to this committee was either inadequate or wrong, that there were matters that were suppressed or that there was any reason at all for this committee to be re-opened. It seems to us to be another waste of time, a further frustration of the government's business, and for that reason we will vote against it.

speech.speaker: Bolkus, Sen Nick

talk.start.para: —by leave—In moving this motion today, I make it very clear that we are talking about an incident which involves two departments—the Department of Administrative Services and the Attorney‐General's Department. The money for this campaign run by the Attorney‐General's Department comes from the Medicare levy which was extended and paid for in good faith by Australian taxpayers. That department has had to come back to the Senate to correct one answer, as Senator Hill indicated in respect of DAS. We have had the same situation in respect of the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board—their chief executive officer had to also correct an answer. On that basis, Senator Hill, I think you would be inclined to change your mind and accept that there has been a correction of evidence here.

speech.para:
We are also talking about answers provided since the last hearing and answers not provided. It is a very critical issue for the Australian government and Australian governments to know when this campaign is going to start. We were given advice some three weeks ago that creative work would be ready by now, that the campaign should be off and running by about the middle of November and that states would be involved in it as well. But in
answers to questions in the House of Representatives, Mr Williams, the Attorney-General, could not commit himself to timing; he could not say why he chose the wrong campaign; he could not say why the focus of the campaign was changed; he was not able to table critical documents of A‐G's—in fact, he refused to table documents of advice from the Attorney-General's Department in respect of the focus of this campaign.

talk.start.para: —The questions don't relate to the commencement of the program.

—A lot of these of issues have arisen because of information provided since and information provided not just in the estimates process but also in the House of Representatives. We have found out in recent days that Mr Williams tried to answer whether OGIA was directed to the Liberal Party or to the Attorney-General's office to find DDB Needham at a critical stage. An issue that remains outstanding is that there are inconsistencies in the Attorney's advice and in information to the parliament and to the broader public.

speech.para: For instance, we did not get an answer—we are waiting for this—as to whether information had been provided to DDB Needham before other tenderers in terms of the quality of the research. So there are a lot of issues outstanding here. This process will not really be completed unless both committees can get into it again, given the inconsistencies and inadequacies of answers since we last met.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

The various provisions of the bill should be seen in the context of the government's commitment to
quality, diversity and innovative change in the higher education sector. This bill meets the government's savings tasks in the fairest way, while advancing key objectives for the higher education sector. It also sets the framework on which the sector can build for the future.

A number of amendments in the bill provide supplementation for price movements. This supplementation covers items such as superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals, special capital projects, grants to open learning organisations and certain grants in respect of the year 1998.

The government is committed to strengthening Australia's research and training capacity. To achieve this objective, the bill provides for increased research funding for Australian postgraduate awards and collaborative research of over $39 million and a further $90 million for increases in research infrastructure.

Through this bill, the government is further encouraging the participation of equity groups in higher education by introducing up to 4,000 merit equity scholarships between 1997 and 2000. The scholarships will provide a Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) exemption to recipients, and will be awarded by universities on the basis of merit, consistent with guidelines. The scholarships may only be accessed by members of a nominated equity group.

This initiative is in addition to maintenance of the existing higher education equity program at an annual cost of $5.8 million, providing incentive funding to institutions to achieve improved outcomes for students from equity groups. Further, the government will also maintain the regional disability liaison officer initiative for another year at a cost of $750,000, to co‐ordinate the provision of services for students with disabilities.

The bill introduces additional opportunities and choice for Australian students by removing the prohibitions on offering fee‐paying places to Australian undergraduate students. This will remove the existing anomaly in the treatment of Australian and overseas students.

This measure will enable Australian students to have a greater chance of obtaining the higher education course of their first preference, freeing up government funded places they would have otherwise accepted with their second or third preference. It will also generate additional income for the universities and will provide an extra incentive for diversity among institutions.

The overwhelming majority of students will continue to contribute to the costs of their education through the HECS alone. The government will not allow institutions to substitute fee‐paying places for HECS‐only places, nor will they be able to move whole undergraduate courses on to a fee‐paying basis.

The number of fee‐paying places available to Australian undergraduate students will be limited to twenty five per cent of domestic undergraduate students in any course. If an institution offers fee‐paying places while at the same time failing to fill its undergraduate target with HECS‐liable students, a financial penalty of $9,000 will apply for each place.

Under current funding arrangements, if universities enrol more than the target number of Australian students, they receive no extra funding even though the Commonwealth receives HECS payments from the students. The government is removing this anomaly.

From 1998, universities will be paid the equivalent of the minimum up‐front HECS payment for each HECS‐liable undergraduate student enrolled above the target level. This provides some recognition of the costs incurred by institutions which over‐enrol. It will also present an opportunity for institutions with low marginal costs to offer additional places to undergraduate students without charging fees.

The bill introduces differential HECS contributions from 1997. This measure strikes a better balance between the public and private funding of higher education. Students will now be required to make a contribution to the cost of their education which is more closely linked to both the actual cost of the course undertaken and the likely future benefits to the individual in terms of increased life‐time earnings.

The bill provides that the new HECS charges will apply in three bands: $3,300, $4,700 and $5,500. Each unit of study will be allocated to one of the bands. A student commencing a course in 1997 will have their HECS debt calculated according to the distribution of their units between each of the three bands. The student will be charged at the appropriate band amount for each unit, rather than being charged at the same band for all units.

In introducing the new differential HECS arrangements, the amendments ensure that no existing student will have an unanticipated increase in the cost of their current course. The government will not be increasing the HECS charge or debt levels for existing debtors or for HECS‐liable students in their current courses. The new charges will only apply to students commencing a new course after 1 January 1997. The arrangements retain the essential features of HECS and ensure that no qualified student is prevented from entering higher education because of an inability to pay at the time of enrolment.

Consistent with this measure, the bill also enables the open learning agency of Australia to set its fees at a level it considers appropriate. At present, the agency is constrained by its agreement with the Commonwealth to charge for undergraduate units at a fixed price. If this constraint is not lifted, the
agency will be required to charge at a level that is below the new differential HECS level, and lower than the level of fees institutions may charge.

Eligible open learning students will continue to be able to defer their charge under the open learning deferred payment scheme. The amount the Commonwealth will lend to the student under the scheme will remain at the level of the current basic charge.

The bill also provides new HECS repayment thresholds, which will mean that individual HECS debtors repay their debt more quickly. The provisions retain seven repayment levels, but set them at lower levels. No student will be required to make HECS repayments until their income reaches the minimum threshold set out in the bill.

The lowering of the minimum threshold to $20,701 means that the current discount for voluntary payment at this income level will be discontinued. The repayment required at this income level will be less than $12 per week. The existing discounts of twenty five per cent for up‐front payments and fifteen per cent for voluntary payments of $500 at any time, will remain.

A new section 20a of the act will clarify that advances of operating grants may be made for a broad range of purposes, consistent with ministerial guidelines. Those guidelines will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and enable advances to be made for redundancy expenses and to assist institutions with the costs associated with restructuring. This amendment is required to clarify an ambiguity with the provisions contained in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996.
The bill also includes a consequential amendment to the act of the Australian Maritime Council to enable it to charge undergraduate fees on the same basis as other higher education institutions.
This bill reflects the government's commitment to a relevant, high quality education system which is striving for excellence and innovation in teaching and research.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996
This bill serves to make various non‐Budget amendments to social security legislation.

The bill makes amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 to rectify an inequity with the mature age partner provisions. From 1 July 1995, wife pension and mature age partner allowance were phased out. However, those people who had claimed these payments and were qualified for them before that date were "saved" from the effect of the changes. The savings provision did not operate as intended for the mature age partner allowance. For example, when a disability pensioner turns 65 years of age and is automatically transferred to age pension, it
was intended that his wife pension partner continue to qualify for wife pension. The Social Security Act did not allow, however, for "saved" mature age partner allowance recipients to continue to receive the mature age partner allowance when their mature age allowance partners are automatically transferred to age pension. This bill makes amendments to rectify this situation.

This bill also makes amendments to continue the effect of savings provisions in clause 54 of Schedule 1A. Clause 54 provides a series of savings provisions which applied to maintain the status quo of various groups of family allowance recipients who were overseas when the family payment regime commenced operation on 1 January 1993. If not for these savings provisions, these people, who formerly received an add‐on for dependent children as a component of their pension, would not have been qualified for the new family payment.

However, clause 54 makes reference to "additional family payment", which ceased to exist on 1 January 1996. In the absence of the amendments made by this bill, clause 54 would not operate to provide the correct rate of payment for these people.

Under the Social Security Act, a person's assets may affect payment of their social security pension, benefit or allowance. This bill amends the Social Security Act to ensure that payments of financial assistance from the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust to persons with medically acquired HIV infection and AIDS (and payments to the dependents and carers of such persons) are not taken into account for the purposes of the social security assets test.

Finally the bill amends the Social Security Act to rectify a technical problem with a provision in Pension Rate Calculator A. When the Social Security Act was amended in 1992 to integrate family allowance and family allowance supplement into a new payment (family payment), some inappropriate consequential amendments were made to a provision dealing with how a person's reduction for ordinary income is to be worked out in the situation of a person who is a member of a couple and has a partner receiving a social security or service pension
I commend the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Order! The committee is considering the bill as a whole and Senator Sherry's amendments Nos 1 to 12 to schedule 3. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —When the consideration of this bill was interrupted last Thursday for the adjournment, Senator Campbell, the parliamentary secretary, was saying:

speech.para: I am advised, just to reinforce that point, Senator Margetts, that the government is considering delegating and contracting advice given to the community groups. That means resources. Maybe you will change your mind and vote for the schedule now.

We were asking for resources to be guaranteed for the community groups. Perhaps we could check whether that was a fault in the
Hansard
or not. But I would also like to clarify that it was a case of between the devil
and the deep blue sea in this regard. We do not see that the Employment Advocate is a great boon for employees in the workplace system; that is, in the brave new world of the post workplace relations bill.

In my opinion, there will be a great need for good, reliable and independent advice. I do not see that the way the government and the Australian Democrats have set things up will guarantee that. Therefore, the current arrangements, inadequate as they are, even with the Department of Industrial Relations, might be better than the situation, with its implied conflict of interest, that would exist with what the government proposes for the Employment Advocate.

To clarify the situation: no, it is not a matter of our saying, `Na, na, na, you didn't support our amendments.' I gather that there will be further proposals with the recommittal of that proposed section. We will be looking at those very carefully, and hopefully so will the rest of the Senate, to make sure that this provision will do, at least partly, what it is supposed to do—assist workers in dealing with the very many problems that they will be encountering with individual contracts.

I just thought I would clarify that. We are not saying that it was nearly good enough. We are saying, `What a dreadful situation you have put workers in. How on earth can we create a better situation to make sure there is some redress for them?'

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para:
—I have not read the
Hansard
over the weekend. I believe that the statement I made was that the government is giving active consideration to delegating to community organisations in respect of the matters raised by Senator Margetts.

—My question goes to the issue of free legal representation to parties proceeding under the proposed act if the Employment Advocate considers it would promote the enforcement of the provisions of the act. Under what circumstances will legal representation be denied?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —There are no guidelines in relation to that at this stage. That is something that will evolve.
—When will those guidelines be available?
—As I said, those are matters which will evolve. I did not say that there were any guidelines. I said that there are no guidelines, and there might not be any guidelines. There is none at the moment.
—Are you saying there will or will not be guidelines with regard to legal representation?
—That is a matter for the Employment Advocate to determine as the issue arises.
—Does the government have a policy that there should be guidelines with regard to this matter?

—That could be a matter on which the minister could direct, under the provisions we discussed last Thursday, if the need emerges. The government's policy at this stage is for the Employment Advocate to determine the matter.
—Does that mean that the government will be considering doing this by way of regulation? If so, I presume that the regulations would be disallowable?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —My understanding is that if Senator Mackay or Senator Hogg came in here in six months time and said that it was absolutely imperative that there be a set of guidelines, that is something the minister would be able to do by direction. As we agreed last Thursday, in a majority vote of this chamber, that is an instrument that would be disallowable.

—I note under 83BP that the Employ
ment Advocate would give advice to both parties—the employer and employee. Is there any indemnity under the proposed act for the Employment Advocate against being sued for having given wrong advice?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the same sorts of rules that apply to a whole range of Commonwealth agencies in respect to giving advice would apply here. There is no specific immunity or indemnity under the act. A whole range of Commonwealth agencies give advice on a daily basis. There is no special consideration given in this act that would make it any different from others that legislate for all those other agencies.

—My next question relates to proposed section 83BS, which refers to the identity of AWA parties not being disclosed. It says that an `entrusted person' must not disclose protected information, and there is provision for a penalty of imprisonment for six months. Firstly, is that the maximum or minimum penalty? Secondly, does that apply even when a person does not intend to disclose but the information becomes available or known?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The person to which the penalty would apply would have to actively disclose it, and that is a maximum penalty.

—I will just go to the fundamental question with regard to the dual role, alluded to by my colleagues last week, that is played by the Employment Advocate. Can the parliamentary secretary please indicate how the dual role is in fact going to be clearly delineated within the Office of Employment Advocate and, in fact, whether it can be, given that that person will be both advice giver and prosecutor?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role:
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the
Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —That would be a matter for administrative organisation by the Office of Employment Advocate.

—I am not sure that that is a particularly adequate answer, with respect. Perhaps my question should be directed through the parliamentary secretary to Senator Murray, with regard to the position put by the Democrats in the minority report. They have clearly indicated that their preference was two offices, effectively. The first one was an employee ombudsman and the second was an employee advocate, with those two roles clearly delineated. Through the parliamentary secretary to Senator Murray: if that was a priority, Senator Murray, with regard to the Democrats' position in the minority report, why is the clear delineation of those two functions not a priority now?
—It is actually through the chair to Senator Murray.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats took the clear view that it was right and proper that the government should have the opportunity to introduce a new institution to add to the existing industrial relations institutions if they felt that that was an appropriate innovation. With the introduction of any new institution, there are, inevitably, areas of some lack of clarity—whether the budget will be sufficient, whether the organisational structure is sufficient, whether the tasks, roles and responsibilities are appropriate, and whether the officers to run the institution have a clear understanding of their role.

speech.para:
You quite rightly point out that we regarded, as a result of the evidence given to us, that the employee ombudsman model, as shown in South Australia, was a very admirable model and one which seemed to work very well. It remains our preferred model. But the essence is that the government did not agree at this stage to introducing our preference and wished to take the development of this institution along the lines they originally envisaged. As a consequence, there may be areas of some conflict which could develop,
such as those outlined by Professor Ron McCallum and others; there may be some problems as a result of a dualistic role, and some conflicts may arise out of that.

My own belief is that we should give the government the opportunity to experiment and to live with this for a while. We should give the unions the opportunity to deal with and interact with that institution. We should give employer organisations the opportunities to deal with and interact with that organisation so that, in due course, after some months of experimentation and understanding as to how it is to work, they can make the appropriate recommendations for its further development. It is, in my view—and obviously yours—not going to be perfect, as it is envisaged. But the government badly want it to work, so I am quite sure that, if it does not work as effectively as they might want it to, they are likely to look favourably at changes.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —Senator, you have said that there will be a sort of conflict between both giving advice and being a prosecuting agency. The government envisages that a majority role of the Employment Advocate will be advice, assistance and representation.

speech.para: If matters came up that required any prosecution, that would not be the core role of that agency—those matters would be handed to another agency. Apparently that is the case with industrial award inspectors, for example, where, if they find a breach, they would then refer it to Attorney-General's for prosecution. So we do not envisage that being a significant area of conflict.

talk.start.para:
—I thank Senator Murray and Senator Campbell for their answers. I am just curious to pursue this, in light of the answer given by Senator Campbell. I am curious to pursue precisely where the prosecution functions would go and under what circumstances would those prosecution functions go to whichever agency you are referring to. Sec
ondly, if that is the case, why have the dual role enshrined in legislation?

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —That is a matter for the Employment Advocate to determine when it is established. There are, as I have said, a number of other agencies which do, from time to time, have to prosecute and refer them to Attorney-General's by way of example. The core answer is that that is a matter for the Employment Advocate to determine when that office is established, which will be some time after the Senate passes this bill.
—Just on that same point: under what circumstances would the Employment Advocate pursue prosecution—himself or herself or his or her office?

—I think the answer to that is similar to the answer to the question you asked in relation to where assistance would be denied. It is a matter for the Employment Advocate to determine. They would be very good matters to raise at Senate estimates, for example, or at committees that deal with these things. Once the Employment Advocate office is established, you could assess those matters then.

speech.para: The fair answer is that, if you wanted to define all of those matters in the bill, you would reduce the flexibility that the Employment Advocate and the Office of the Employment Advocate will have when they are established. As Senator Murray quite rightly said, this is something that the government wants to make work. Either you can be quite prescriptive, and limit the Employment Advocate's opportunities, or you can ensure that the objects and the intentions are implemented in the way we have described.

talk.start.para: —With respect, Senator Campbell, I think you may have just proved the opposition's point. Surely, if the major part of the Employment Advocate's role is advice giving and so on and the prosecution functions are to be farmed out—to where, we have not been illuminated—why would you have this dual role in the same office?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —My response three interventions previously has already answered that question.

—With respect, you did not answer it in a policy sense. In a policy sense, the question I am asking, through you, Mr Chairman—and I do not want to restate it—is why should we have the dual function if one of those functions, the prosecution role, is essentially going to be farmed off. I do not believe that that question has been adequately answered by the parliamentary secretary, and I would appreciate a fuller response.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The government is mindful of potential conflicts, but we do not see this as being as much of a problem as you do. However, I do respect your views and concerns.

—Following on from that point, where do employees go if they are dissatisfied with the advice provided by the Employment Advocate or if the Employment Advocate somehow proves to be incompetent? Is there some form of redress for those employees—or it could be employers, for that matter?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —Like most Commonwealth agencies, the office will obviously seek to provide the best level of service that it possibly can.
—So, for example, there is no redress available by going to the ombudsman or someone such as that if one finds fault in the quality of the advice given by the Employment Advocate?
—There is no provision in the act for any second guessing of that sort of advice.

speech.speaker: Evans, Sen Chris

talk.start.para: —I want to ask the parliamentary secretary a question regarding the Employment Advocate's duties contained in the government/Democrat amendments. The relevant amendment states:

speech.para: . . . the Employment Advocate must have particular regard to:
(a) the needs of workers in a disadvantaged bargaining position—
What does that mean? What will the Employment Advocate do for those people who are allegedly in a disadvantaged bargaining position?

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans, the bill makes specific mention of having special mind to the needs of disadvantaged people. We are sending a message from the parliament to the Office of the Employment Advocate to ensure that those groups that need assistance get it. That assistance may be very different from city to city, suburb to suburb. It may be different for different disadvantaged groups.

speech.para: Again, that is not something that needs to be prescribed in the legislation. The Office of the Employment Advocate will have the discretion to ensure that assistance for disadvantaged groups and individuals is delivered in a way that is most helpful to those groups and individuals.

talk.start.para:
—My understanding of the way the Employment Advocate system will work is that the advocate will be presented with an agreement reached by the parties. The advocate will then review that agreement to ensure it meets the minimum requirements. How, then, will the Employment Advocate give special regard to the needs of those workers if the workers approach the advocate with an agreement that has disadvantaged them because they are from a non-English speaking background, they are young or what have
you? What actions will the Employment Advocate take to give effect to this high sounding rhetoric? What will the Employment Advocate actually do?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —Perhaps Senator Evans does misunderstand the concept of the OEA. They are not just there to receive an agreement that is finalised. They are there to provide advice and assistance in the formulation of the agreement in the first place. Through this provision, the OEA have been asked to give special regard to the needs of the disadvantaged. They will be able to organise themselves and provide that advice in the most appropriate manner, just as they will provide advice in the formulation of those agreements.

speech.speaker: Evans, Sen Chris

talk.start.para: —I am having a little trouble understanding that concept. My understanding is that the Employment Advocate will provide assistance and advice to employers. That advice could be about the minimum conditions they have to meet in filing an agreement, for example. At the same time, the Employment Advocate will help remedy the disadvantage that the government recognises certain groups of workers face. I am not sure how the Employment Advocate is going to be able to balance those two demands.

speech.para: What I am trying to get at is the function that the Employment Advocate will have in relation to these people who your own legislation says are in a disadvantaged bargaining position. What action will the Employment Advocate take to redress that disadvantaged bargaining position those workers find themselves in, given that at the same time you are advising the employers how they can maximise their interests in this process?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para:
—An example for Senator Evans is that the OEA may indeed give advice to a person who is suffering
disadvantage to get assistance in the bargaining process, possibly from a union.

—Do I take it from that that the Employment Advocate will be going into the work force talking to people who are not currently in an agreement and seeking to give them advice prior to their entering into agreements? I understood their role was more one of responding to agreements that were put before them, but you are now indicating that they have got a sort of proactive role in the work force, in the community. Is that is right?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I had indicated the role in the answer I gave four interventions previously; that is, that they are not restricted to giving advice on agreements that are lodged with them; they are able to give advice to people who are seeking advice while negotiating an agreement.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —I would like to add to the response of the parliamentary secretary on this matter. Senator Evans, the evidence before the Senate inquiry clearly indicated—in fact proved—that there are groups of employees and, indeed, groups of employers, and individual employees and employers, who have relative advantages and disadvantages in the bargaining process. Coming from a side of the chamber which is well represented in union negotiation, you would understand that to be a truth.

speech.para:
Our intention, which I think I spelt out in earlier remarks made last week, was that the standard even‐handed arbitration and conciliation process of the AIRC should, wherever possible, be supplemented in this legislation by a bias towards those who are disadvantaged. It is quite plain that, in the early days of the establishment of this new institution, the way in which that is to be implemented is still up in the air, and you quite rightly point out that that is not yet spelt out finitely. But I think the parliamentary secretary is correct in wanting to leave that open ended and let
the Employment Advocate develop some of the strengths of his or her own institution.

I should make the point that amongst a number of consequences of the amendment process will be requirements that all AWAs include appropriate provisions on discrimination, that an AWA is offered to all comparable employees, that the employer explain the effect of an AWA to the employee, and that the employee genuinely consented to making an AWA. If the employer is explaining the effect of an AWA to a non-English speaking person, plainly that person is potentially at a disadvantage unless it has been properly presented. We would expect the Employment Advocate to have consideration for that.

We say that these considerations will be most important in the development of the information statement prepared by the Employment Advocate, which all employers will be required to give to employees prior to signing an AWA. Whilst you may wish to categorise these statements about disadvantaged employees as somewhat motherhood, we are hopeful that they can be developed into a proper protection which does not currently exist.

speech.speaker: Evans, Sen Chris

talk.start.para: —I appreciate Senator Murray's intervention and that of the parliamentary secretary. I will, however, make a couple of points, because I do not seem to be able to get the answers I want as to how this operates in practice. The first thing is that, from reading the report of the committee looking into the bill, I understood that those concerns that were raised in evidence were the very concerns that led Senator Murray to recommend the separation of the offices to an advocate and an ombudsman's role to deal with that very conflict. I do not want to labour the point but, again, we do not see that contained in the legislation or the agreed amendments.

speech.para:
The second aspect is that one of the reasons these workers are at a disadvantage is that they are being discouraged and prevented, in some instances, from collectively bargaining. We are not giving any encouragement to collective bargaining, so in many cases they
will be negotiating these agreements individually and relying on the employer to explain to them their rights. Anyone with any modicum of experience in industrial relations knows that there is potential for abuse.

The other point I make is that, from my experience of the Western Australian system, there are allegedly protections in terms of people having agreements explained to them, along with the workplace commissioner allegedly protecting people's rights. The reality of the experience is quite different from that. The commissioner merely seeks some acknowledgment from the workers that they have some idea of what they are signing, then does no more. A number of documented cases were presented in evidence to the committee about how unsuccessful that has been.

The other reason for my cynicism is that the last time the coalition had a go at industrial relations legislation at the federal level, they introduced a similar clause in the charter of the Industrial Relations Bureau which called for a particular focal point on non-English speaking workers. That, quite frankly, was an unmitigated failure. They never achieved any of their objectives in looking after those people disadvantaged by an inability to speak English. It really is, in my view, a sop. We have not had any proper explanation of how someone can advise an employer and, at the same time, take some proactive role in trying to redress the disadvantaged bargaining position that the legislation recognises. It is a nonsense. There is no explanation, and that is why one has not been presented.

talk.start.para: —I am following on from the contribution made by Senator Evans. I ask Senator Murray: did the Democrats, in negotiations with the government, seek any specific guarantees on the role of the Employment Advocate Office, given the Democrats' clear position in their report on the splitting of the dual role?

—In response to Senator Mackay, there are no guarantees other than those that
you see before you outlined in the agreement, which is a public document.
—I want to ask a question about 83BB and the amendments of the government and the Australian Democrats. It is just another literal.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are actually debating the opposition's amendments; we are not debating the government's amendments. Perhaps Senator Cooney was unaware of that.
—I understand that.
—The question before the chair is Senator Sherry's amendments 1 to 12.
—Which gets rid of your section, so it is reasonable to ask why.

—Thanks very much and thanks for bringing all that to my mind. I propose: wouldn't the propositions put forward by the opposition perhaps broaden the present position to the point you would seem to be wanting it brought to? Senator Murray, the amendments that you are proposing to schedule 3, item 2, page 8, after line 14, at the end of section 83BB, would not seem to broaden the present 83BB functions to the extent that you might want.
Would it not be better, for the reasons already put forward, for the opposition amendments to go through? They seem to come closer to what I think you want, Senator Murray, than your present amendments would. Clearly, you do not want me to explain those to you, from the objections made. But, if you do want that, I will explain them to you.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —Responding to Senator Cooney, I must make the remark that I have noticed in debates that you are one of the senators that is, generally speaking, kissed, not kicked. So I will deal with you in the normally polite way people do when they respond to you.

speech.para:
Having said that in jest, I do want to make a couple of serious points. The first is that it is self‐evident to everyone in this chamber and listening that the government definitely gave up what they did not want to give up and the Australian Democrats definitely did not get everything we wanted to get. Quite
plainly, what you have before you is the result of negotiation and compromise.

Since we are dealing with the amendments 1 to 12 reviewing the whole area of the Employment Advocate, I really do want to respond to the question of limbo. It is my view that the government have very properly said, `We have to deal with an area of individual agreements between employees and employers which, at this point in time, are informal. They are out there but they are in some sort of legal limbo.'

You and I both know that two‐thirds of employees are not unionised. You and I both know—and I use the collective `you', not the disrespectful `you'—that large numbers of employees are presently on verbal contracts. It is my belief—and has been my belief consistently—that the introduction of Australian workplace agreements, provided that the protections are there, will contribute to a better legal relationship between employees and employers than presently exists. That is one of the reasons that we are prepared to give the government—to use a colloquialism—a fair go in the development of this institution and in the Australian workplace agreements area.

I can see you are dying to hop onto your feet to debate this issue. We really have to accept that, even if you regard it as imperfect, it is an attempt to deal with an area of contractual relationship which in my view and in the view of many others is inadequately and insufficiently dealt with at present.

talk.start.para: —I can understand what Senator Murray is saying. All I am saying is that the amendments that have been put forward by the government and the Australian Democrats really do not take the matter any further—I do not want an answer now, but will perhaps later on in the week—whereas the opposition's amendments may be closer to what I think you are trying to get at in your amendments. Perhaps it is a matter that should be looked at overnight.

speech.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—I just want to make a few comments before we conclude this schedule. That last
comment of Senator Murray was about these contractual agreements that are verbal and not in writing. I think Senator Murray—through you, Mr Chairman—you really are showing your lack of knowledge of the industrial area.

speech.para:
Yes, there have always been many hundreds, and probably millions, of agreements that are verbal—so‐called over‐award agreements that are usually verbal, sometimes in writing. These agreements—in limbo, as you refer to them—will always exist. If you believe what you have just said, the Office of Employment Advocate, as we understand very clearly in this bill, is not to try to take some sort of control of or act as some sort of imprimatur on currently verbal agreements. I am sure that is not what the government has in mind.
The current verbal agreements that exist will continue. There might be some—I suspect very few—that are put down in writing, but that is not the role of an Employment Advocate.

We question the whole reasoning for the creation of the Employment Advocate. As we pointed out earlier, the Department of Industrial Relations provides advice and assistance about awards and AWAs at the moment. We have investigations into breaches or contraventions. The commission also has a role in respect of the filing of AWAs. Why create another organisation to oversee these jurisdictions where this work is already being carried out? It is a duplication. I thought this government was all about cutting away duplication, not adding to it.

The other contradiction, Senator Murray, that you admit—through you, Mr Chairman—is the contradiction between the representational role for employees and employers. If an employee who has a complaint complains to the Employment Advocate and then the Employment Advocate interviews the employer, who is the Employment Advocate to represent? They have to make a choice. There is a clear conflict there. This government does not recognise the clear conflict of interest about shares and they certainly cannot recognise it here. Senator Murray, you recognise it, yet you are supporting the government's position and you are not supporting an
amendment that we moved that reflects your position.

It is a ridiculous situation you are in. You refer to our amendments that reflect your position as being your preferred model. Why aren't you supporting it here today? You say you anticipate some problems, so why aren't you supporting our amendments here today? You say that this is an experiment. Well, we are going to experiment with conflict, knowing there is going to be conflict of interest. You say that this is not going to be perfect. Let us make it as perfect as we can; support our amendments.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I am not sure whether I made it clear before but I am making it clear now that I will be supporting the ALP's amendments. The reason is that we now see a movement towards removing some of that distinct conflict of interest. That surely is preferable if what you are trying to do is achieve those things which have been mentioned by the government and the Democrats today. I would like to think there is still some chance of support in the chamber for doing the things which all of us seem to indicate we should be doing.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
(16)
Schedule 5, items 1 to 5, page 23 (lines 5 to 26), omit the items, substitute:
Insert:

allowable award matters
means the matters covered by subsection 89A(2).
Insert:

exceptional matters order
means an order made by the Commission on a matter that is allowed to be included in an industrial dispute because of subsection 89A(6).

2 Subsection 4(1) (definition of paid rates award
)

)
Repeal the definition.

means an employee who:

(a)

(b)

(a)

para.tab:
(i)

speech.para:
