This amendment contains two new definitions for exceptional matters orders and regular part‐time employees. Exceptional matters orders are to be an important part of the protection for employees under the new amended act. These will allow the AIRC to arbitrate on issues that are exceptional, that is, outside the allowable matters where the parties cannot agree and where the outcome would otherwise be harsh or unjust.

These exceptional matters orders are not designed to ensure that the commission has the powers to fulfil the object of the act of providing for a labour market that is fair as well as flexible. They will provide a particular level of protection for employees in a weak bargaining position who might otherwise be unable to prevent an employer imposing a harsh or unjust outcome on them.

The definition of regular part‐time employee is also important. This definition is based
on the wording of the AIRC itself in the personal carer's leave case. In particular, the AIRC will be required under proposed section 143(1)(caa) to ensure that awards, where appropriate, contain part‐time employment provisions. This should accelerate the acceptance of part‐time work across awards, combined with a ban introduced by this bill on quotas and maximum hours for part‐time employees.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —We oppose the government‐Democrat amendments to these particular provisions. We indeed oppose and do not agree with the provisions in this part of the bill. We will be making a number of points about the issues raised here at a later stage of debate when we will make known our individual views.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —Amendment 16 that we have been asked to consider deals with the insertion of definitions related to allowable award matters, exceptional award matters, regular part‐time employees and state employment agreements. The elimination in the bill of definitions relating to paid rates awards is maintained. Some of the new definitions could be considered to be an improvement on the current situation but the loss of paid rates awards is consistent with the unchallenged government intention of clause 37.

speech.para: Therefore, on balance, it is not my intention to support this amendment. I notice that this amendment is in conflict also with the ALP amendments 13 to 17, which in fact oppose items 1 to 5 of the bill. I would also like to flag that I am more inclined to support the amendments which oppose items 1 to 5 in relation especially to paid awards because this is pivotal in what we have ended up with and what the working people of Australia will have ended up with as a result of this bill going through—or being pushed through.
Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para:
—Mr Temporary Chairman, there have been further amend
ments on behalf of the government and the Australian Democrats which have been circulated to all senators. These are amendments to the amendments that we are dealing with now.

speech.para: These amendments, which are additional to those circulated last week, are minor technical, clarifying amendments which reflect the agreed government‐Australian Democrats position. These further amendments include amendments in respect of schedule 5. The further amendments alter the amendments that were circulated last week. Accordingly, when I move government‐Democrat amendments in relation to which further amendments are proposed I will be moving those amendments, as amended.

speech.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —The opposition proposes to omit the following items:

speech.para:
(13)
Schedule 5, item 1, page 23 (lines 5 to 8), omit the item.

(14)
Schedule 5, item 2, page 23 (lines 9 to 10), omit the item.

(15)
Schedule 5, item 3, page 23 (lines 11 to 12), omit the item.

(16)
Schedule 5, item 4, page 23 (lines 13 to 15), omit the item.

(17)
Schedule 5, item 5, page 23 (lines 16 to 26), omit the item.

I just make a couple of points because we recognise the continuing unfortunate stability of this voting block we are faced with here today—the Liberal‐Democrat deal on this bill. There are points we can make with respect to our proposal later in discussion on schedule 5.

I briefly explain the reasons for our opposition to amendments 13 to 17. We delete the new definition of `allowable award matters'. We do not accept the concept of allowable award matters in any way, shape or form and we will be making some comment on that later. We delete the bill's repeal of the definition of `paid rates award', `paid rates dispute' and `paid rates functions and powers'. We do not believe that deletion is appropriate and, again, we will deal with that in some detail shortly. We delete the new definition of `state employment agreement' as a consequence of
our proposed deletion of the bill's provisions which permit state employment agreements. We deal with that in amendment 50 in respect of their override of the act.
Items 1 to 5, as amended, agreed to.

(17)
Schedule 5, item 6, page 24 (lines 3 to 9), omit paragraphs (a), (b) and (c), substitute:

(a)
wages and conditions of employment are protected by a system of enforceable awards established and maintained by the Commission; and

(b)
awards act as a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions of employment; and

(c)
awards are simplified and suited to the efficient performance of work according to the needs of particular workplaces or enterprises; and

speech.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —We oppose this amendment, amendment 17, with respect to objects and, indeed, we obviously oppose the original provision in the bill. With respect to the Labor proposal that we will be dealing with shortly, the bill deletes the existing section providing for the objects of part 6, prevention and settlement of disputes, and inserts new objects.

speech.para: Our amendment amends these new objects in the following ways—and this encapsulates our opposition to the proposals the government has in this bill and with respect to its amendment 17. Firstly, we say that minimum wages and conditions must be protected and maintained at relevant and fair levels by the award system. Secondly, we say that awards must provide relevant, secure and consistent wages and conditions. Thirdly—and this is a key point that I hope Senator Murray will have some regard to—whilst accepting that awards must be suited to the efficient performance of work, we add that the interests of employees must also be taken into account.

Frankly, it is a surprise to me that the Democrats did not deal with this matter in their negotiations with the government. Fourthly, whilst accepting that the commission's award making powers should encourage the making of workplace agreements, we add that they must also encourage
the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. In this objects section, we do not have the encouragement of the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. That is a fundamental change in industrial relations.

For 100 years—Senator Murray may not be aware of this—one of the objects of the act since Federation has been the settlement of industrial disputes. It seems to us that that is still a fundamental—a core, if we want to use current parlance in respect of promises—commitment or object that should be included in this section. What is more fundamental than encouraging the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes? Why doesn't it appear here, Senator Murray? It should do. We would argue strongly, Senator Murray, that you should support the inclusion of this in this section. My colleagues intend to make some further observations about these provisions. But that is the overview of our concern in respect of this part of the bill.

talk.start.para: —Schedule 5 has been, as we can see, amended slightly by amendment 17 of the government and Democrats. But paragraph (b) still encounters the kind of problems we talked about when we were talking about the object of the bill—that is, we have got the words `awards act as a safety net of fair minimum wages'. We never did find what was meant by `fair'. We discovered it could mean anything from a fairground carousel to moderately good. If that is what stands between something reasonable for workers and potential exploitation, I am not very hopeful, I am afraid. With regard to `awards are simplified', that is one way of putting it.
—Gutted!

—Yes, `gutted' could be the other word. Most of the allowable elements have been removed. With regard to `suited to the efficient performance of work', it does tend to link up with the international competitiveness. So whilst there might be minimal improvements in schedule 5, I am more inclined—we know that the numbers will be there for this amendment 17 to go through, anyway—to support the ALP's amendment to this schedule.

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para: —Amendment 17 states that `wages and conditions of employment are protected by a system of enforceable awards'. You then say that the `awards act as a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions of employment'. But it says that the awards are to be `established and maintained by the commission'. Is it contemplated that the commission will somehow be a self‐starter on this, that you will not need a log of claims? If that is what is meant, how can the commission do that? I am just wondering what the additional words in the amendment envisage. If you look at the original workplace relations bill, it says that the `wages and conditions of employment are protected by a system of enforceable awards'. But you have added the words `established and maintained by the commission'. They must mean something.

speech.para: It would seem to mean that somehow the commission, on its own initiative, is going to establish and maintain a system of enforceable awards. I would be interested to know how that could happen. In paragraph (b) you have changed the words `are confined in their scope' to `act as a safety net'. Again, I wonder what real effect that change will have. When it says `confined in their scope to a safety net', that means it cannot be any more than that, but when you use the words `act as a safety net' it cannot mean any more than being a safety net. I was wondering what is contemplated by those two amendments.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para:
—In relation to `establish and maintain', the establishment processes remain as they are, that is, the initiating mechanisms are the same. So you could have a log of claims. In relation to the safety net and the establishment of the safety net, they are as they are set out in the bill. They are very similar to the sorts of words that were included in a number of the Keating Labor government's submissions, for example, to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, very similar in wording to the statements made in Working Nation, and words repeated
in the ALP's January 1996 policy statement, where the concept of providing a safety net of minimum standards by the award system was repeated.

—From that answer, I take it that it is contemplated that the commission will establish and maintain the award system on the basis of what the unions in effect put to them as a log of claims. Is it confined to that—to the settlement of logs of claim?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I am informed and advised that there is no self-starting procedure. The initiation process is exactly as it stands now.

—Perhaps just a further clarification arising from Senator Cooney's question. What then does the commission do, given that we have removed the requirement for the commission to encourage the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes in a general sense, in relation to industrial disputes with reference to logs of claims involving non-allowable matters?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The conciliation powers of the commission are unfettered.

—Can I then infer from that that its arbitration powers are obviously limited? Given that we are in this general area and that an answer was not forthcoming when I was covering the general objects of the bill, perhaps we can revisit an issue that Senator Murray raised. With respect to awards now referring to what are just safety nets—so we no longer have what we have regarded for near on a century as the award system but rather just safety nets, which might just as well be 20 minimum standards rather than an award system—and given that is what we are left with in this bill, I did not take Senator Murray literally when he was saying that
matters which were `exceptional' were those which were non-allowable. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary would at this stage give us some indication or some guidance on what are to be regarded as exceptional matters in terms of how we should read this object in relation to an award safety net.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The exceptional matters are matters that are described as being unusual and where harshness or unjust treatment can be proven.

—With respect, Parliamentary Secretary, I think there is a separate provision you are relying upon in relation to matters being harsh—I do not quite have the wording in front of me at the moment—as opposed to otherwise. In one sense that appears to be a cross-definition. You have one provision saying that the commission has to take into account matters which might be harsh or, I think, unreasonable and another provision which says `exceptional'. I think we need some further clarification on what is intended there—or certainly the commission will need it.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I think I have answered the question. They are matters that are exceptional. They are not the normal run-of-the-mill cases. But they are two tests in relation to the same definition.

—I seek further clarification on that point. If that is the case, why do we have two separate tests? Why not just the one test—matters which are exceptional, which means matters that are harsh and unreasonable?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para:
—I have answered it
twice. This will be a third time. They have to be exceptional. That is one of the tests. They have to pass both of the tests. They are not exclusive. There should be no confusion.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —I would like to return to Senator Cooney's question. Senator Cooney, your question I would answer as follows—that paragraph (a) is amended to make it clear that awards are to be both `established' and `maintained' by the commission. This word `maintained' is important as it means that the commission has a duty to ensure that awards are up-to-date and are not allowed to decline over time.

speech.para: Secondly, paragraph (b) is to be changed to make it clear that awards will act as a safety net for fair minimum wages and conditions of employment. This is somewhat wider than the original proposal to confine the scope of awards to providing such a safety net. Minimum rates awards provide more than the mere safety net, for `safety net' implies an absolute minimum of conditions. While the provision of a safety net is a desirable object of awards, this new object makes it quite clear that the existence of a safety net is one of the reasons, but clearly not the sole reason, for awards.

Thirdly, paragraph (c) makes it clear that awards are to be simplified as a key object. This is to place up front the clear intention of simple and easier to use awards as a key requirement for this schedule.

talk.start.para: —I am a little confused. How can the commission maintain an award or even establish it unless a claim is made through a log of claims? There are people on this side of the chamber who are much more experienced in this than me, but I cannot see how the commission itself can maintain the awards unless in reality a union in an interstate dispute makes a log of claims. You may have an award established but it would soon get out of date unless a log of claims is served to maintain it. I want to know how you can maintain the award if there is no initiation by a union.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role:
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the
Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —There can be initiation by a union. That is how they can be maintained.

—That is where I am a bit confused. Senator Murray is saying that the Democrats had inserted the word `maintained' because, quite rightly in my view, they were concerned that the awards might decline as time goes by. But how can you get the commission to maintain it if the unions are not there to make the claim? That is what worries me. There does not seem to be any attention given to the issue of how you get the unions to make the claim to maintain the award.

speech.speaker: Forshaw, Sen Michael

talk.start.para: —I just follow on from Senator Cooney's very valid point. We are actually dealing with the very fundamental question of the commission's jurisdiction. The amended bill radically changes the nature of the commission's jurisdiction with respect to, firstly, making findings of industrial disputes and, secondly, resolving them.

speech.para: Senator Campbell, I give you this illustration which might help you to understand the question more, and I would also appreciate Senator Murray's response. We have awards of the commission at the moment. There are quite clearly awards where there are provisions that will not fit into the 18 allowable matters. They may not also be incidental to the 18 allowable matters. I am sure senators on this side of the chamber can give you numerous examples, and you are probably aware of some; I gave one in a speech not so long ago. The question then is: can they be brought in under the head of `exceptional'? That is a test it would appear you are putting forward as something that the commission can determine. You would look at concepts of harsh and unjust and so on.

One of the problems I see here is that there can be a provision in the award at the moment that unless there is some agreement reached as to reflecting that provision by another method—such as an agreement outside the award—it would disappear out of awards in the prescribed period of 18 months.
You then have a position where a union may have to lodge a claim either prior to or after that period to try to get the commission back into the equation to rule upon whether or not this should be an exceptional matter that should be included in the award.

The commission will be faced with the dilemma of saying, `We cannot make a finding of a dispute on that particular issue because it is not an allowable matter.' You have yourself in a real catch‐22 situation. I can tell you that the commission and the High Court have spent a lot of time in the past dealing with the question of what an industrial dispute is for the purposes of exercising not only the powers of the act but the constitutional powers upon which this legislation is based—which you have conveniently left out of the objects.

I am asking you to explain how your proposal will work in matters that you say are exceptional. We want a definition of them; give us some examples. I am putting to you that the commission will find itself in the position of being unable to make a finding of dispute on a particular matter in the first place, thereby enabling it to utilise its conciliation and arbitral powers. Do not respond by saying, as you did, Senator Campbell, that the commission can conciliate. Any industrial relations practitioner will tell you that the commission's powers to conciliate in situations where they do not have specific jurisdiction are only ever exercised if both parties to the industrial situation agree.

You will find, as we often found, that employers will call into question the jurisdiction of the commission. They will go to the act, they will go to this section and they will say, `Hang on! You cannot even get to step one, in terms of determining whether this is exceptional or not, because you cannot even make a valid finding of an industrial dispute under this section in the first place.' That is the problem you are creating. Yet the commission will be dealing with a whole lot of provisions which currently exist in awards and which have been held to be within the meaning of an industrial dispute time and time again.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I really do not think there is a hell of a lot more to add, Senator Forshaw. You do not like the system that we are proposing.
—It's unworkable.
—We said that about another piece of legislation that was debated here at great length back in 1993—
—This is a debate about the jurisdiction of the commission to act—

—I know. The exceptional matters are defined and the commission must be satisfied of all of those points, and you understand that. You do not like the fact that there are now fewer allowable matters and that other matters will have to be proved to be exceptional through meeting this test which is defined. I think it will waste the Senate's time to revisit the various tests. Those who are interested in the debate know what they are. I am happy to read them into the
Hansard
again, but they are in thousands of documents and amendments that are circulating around this place.

speech.para: I respect your view. A lot of people in the industrial area are opposed to what we are doing, but we are taking matters out of their jurisdiction. How matters get back into their jurisdiction through the `exceptional' provisions is a matter that will clearly evolve when this legislation comes into force, if it ever gets through the Senate.

speech.speaker: Forshaw, Sen Michael

talk.start.para:
—Senator Campbell, I think you have just illustrated very well the dilemma that this legislation will create. Fist of all, the word `maintained' has been put in as if it is designed to fix a problem that was seen in this area—which we have been pointing out to you for some time—that comes about because of the reduction to 18 allowable matters. Sure, I do not like it. The primary reason I do not like it is that there are people out there who have entitlements that have been ruled upon by industrial tribunals and, in many cases, may have been upheld by
courts of this land, but this legislation just takes those rights away from them without any real recourse. To suggest that the putting in of the word `maintained' can deal with that position is wrong.

speech.para: Secondly, to suggest, as the Democrats will suggest, that we will create this catch-all subclause so that these matters can all come within the definition of `exceptional' does not advance us any further. The position I am trying to explain to you is that it is said here that this is all about simplification of awards. The primary purpose of section 89A, which we will come to deal with later but which is related, is to simplify awards. Surely, the end result of this is an incredible amount of litigation in the commission and in the courts over what can and what cannot get in because of the restriction on the number of allowable matters.

There will be debates about what is legally meant by the term `exceptional', what is meant by the phrase `harsh and unjust', and what is meant by the word `incidental'. It will not necessarily be the case that you can call on existing precedent to look at those issues, because what we have here is a fundamental change to the definition of an industrial dispute. That is the problem that I am putting to you, and you are saying to us that this is a simplification. How can it be a simplification when what you are really setting up is a regime for a massive amount of litigation from the very first day that this act comes into force?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —There will be litigation when you introduce new provisions. There was litigation when this act came into force under Mr Brereton. We do not dispute there will be litigation.
—Incomparable.

—By interjection Senator Jacinta Collins and others say, `There'll be masses of litigation.' We hope that is not the case. This law is designed to assist working people of Australia, across Australia, through a simplified award system.
—It doesn't simplify it. It makes it more complicated. It's longer to start with.
—I guess so were the amendments to the tax act, the amendments to the Corporations Law and the amendments to the native title act as well—
—You keep reminding us and we are reminding you.

—I am quite happy to be reminded of those things, because we reminded you. We are seeking to do those things. We are not seeking to increase the living standards of lawyers in the industrial field; we are actually seeking to improve the living standards of average Australians. It is not that I have anything against industrial lawyers. I hope genuinely that this bill, if it ever does get through the Senate and comes into law—we have had about 27 hours to date in this debate; we are heading for a record; and on current progress we will take about 150 to 160 hours—will make it better for average working Australians.

break.para: We hope your predictions that there will be masses of litigation are not correct and that the industrial lawyers will not be the net beneficiaries of introducing new provisions. But there was litigation in relation to the new provisions. Unfortunately, Senator Cooney, parliamentary secretaries will not be able to lodge a log of claims on the commission because of section 44 of the constitution.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para:
—I think it would be helpful for Labor to be reminded of page 33 of their
Working Nation
document:

speech.para: The Government sees the process of further reforming awards and removing detailed prescription as vital . . . there is a need to simplify awards—
this is the Labor government—

to make their operation more flexible, while retaining their safety net function. An important role of the AIRC in this regard is to review substantially all Federal awards within a three year time frame and to remedy any deficiencies, such as obsolete and unnecessarily detailed provisions.
I would make the point that, whilst Labor may disagree with government over their implementation, the direction is the same.

talk.start.para: —Mr Chairman, I wanted to ask Senator Murray a question. In relation to questions that Senator Cooney asked about the role of the commission in maintaining the awards and who would pursue that, he was suggesting that if the unions did not pursue it then the commission could not do anything. I thought that Senator Murray quietly interjected `an employer would'. I wanted to ask Senator Murray if he could elaborate on how that would take effect; and what practical means the employer might use in the unlikely event that they were seeking to maintain the awards in the absence of the unions maintaining them?
—My remarks were probably with small business in mind. Small business are very great supporters of the award system, and employer organisations value the awards.

—I just want to follow that point up in relation to the employers maintaining the awards. I think Senator Cooney was making the point that, without an interstate dispute, an individual employer would not have the basis for varying the awards nor would they have the ability to create an interstate dispute binding a variety of employers. So what Senator Murray is suggesting has to be taken to the next step; that is, if there were a selective group of employers who were organised across states then perhaps that could happen. But I would suggest that that is perhaps rather a fanciful view of how the world would operate under this environment, given the history of the maintenance of awards. There have been very few cases where the award system, as it currently stands, has been maintained on application of any employer organisation or individual employer. To suggest that something like this bill will change that is drawing a rather a long bow.

speech.speaker: Collins, Sen Jacinta

talk.start.para:
—There are several points I would like to follow up but, firstly, I want to correct Senator Campbell about my earlier interjection, which was that the level of disputation would be incomparable. Some of the issues touched on to date I feel would be better
addressed as we get into the more detailed provisions of the bill.

speech.para: I note that we are removing from the objects provision a requirement for the commission to encourage prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. The emphasis is obvious. The consequence of this bill is that we will see a significant rise in the level of disputation, reflected not only in the amount of argument that will occur in the Industrial Relations Commission over the meaning of an `allowable matter', an `incidental matter' or an `exceptional matter', but in argument over many other issues as well. For example, what will be regarded as an `industrial dispute'? That is a matter I will follow up later.

To address Senator Murray's comments, I want to go back to the point I made about the objects of this bill. There seems to be a comprehensive misunderstanding or delusion about what our award system is. Senator Murray referred to comments made in
Working Nation
about awards, but nowhere in those comments was there reference to the fact that an award system that deals with more than just minimum safety nets would not continue. The Labor Party never said that and would never have supported that.

We have a feeling for the evolution of the type of industrial system we now have. It deals with more than just 20 minimum standards and the things that might be incidental or exceptional to them. We have worked with the system and we understand how the system works to benefit the nation as a whole in preventing and settling industrial disputes. Now we will have tremendous arguments about what constitutes an industrial dispute. I will come to that later when I deal with the definition of `exceptional matters', because that really highlights the point.

The question I would like to raise at this stage goes back to what Senator Sherry said earlier: we have removed the requirement for the commission to take into account the interests of employees. Why have we done that here? Elsewhere we include the fact that we are supposed to take into account the interests and wishes of employees in relation to union representation. But on the fundamental matter of what goes into an award and
what award conditions are, we remove reference to the interests of employees.

Does that not explain the government's agenda with this bill? Does Senator Murray not see that quite clearly? Does he not see how he has been deluded about some of these things when the government is not prepared to insert a fundamental object in relation to the awards and the award system to take into account the interests of employees? I hope Senator Campbell will answer the specific and clear question: why has the government taken out the provision that refers to the interests of employees?

The other thing that we need to give careful thought to—this was raised a few moments ago—is the way the bill changes the nature of how the system treats representative organisations. What will happen to maintain awards? The notion that the government and the Australian Democrats seem to have about trade unions is that they will be just bargaining agents. That is not the role that unions have played in our industrial relations system to date. How will we maintain this uniform award—I am reluctant to call it an award system—if we do not have representative organisations doing it? That is my second question.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —In response to that second question: there will be representative organisations. The furphy that has been put around by some—I do not accuse Senator Jacinta Collins of it—is that an object of this act is to get rid of the union movement. It is not. There probably will be different unions. Some of the ones we have will get bigger, others smaller, and there will be all sorts of changes, but there will be unions. I predict that in some industries union membership will increase, but it will reflect—
—Which?

—I am not going to try to pick winners, mate; I would not try to do that even tomorrow. I might buy a ticket in my office sweep but I will not be trying to
pick the winner of the race. It is not an object of the government to get rid of unions.
—Aren't you backing Clinton?

—That is another race; I will not make a statement on that. The fact is that there will be representative organisations. Unions will have a different role—an emerging role, a changing role. As you would know, the role of unions has changed a lot over the last 10 years. There are many in the union movement who would say that that role should have changed even more than it has. That is the answer to your second question: they will be there to do a number of those things.

speech.para: Secondly, proposed section 89 provides that the function of the commission is to `prevent and settle industrial disputes'. So the basis of your first question is incorrect. Those words will remain in the act—if passed by the Senate at some stage in the next couple of years.

talk.start.para: —The specific question I was asking related to the removal from the objects of the bill of the requirement to take into account the interests of employees with respect to award making.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The object is to take into account the interests of the whole workplace, and that includes employees and everyone in the workplace. It is a model that is based on getting people to work together as a team and not see each other as being adversaries in every situation.

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para:
—I have one question following what Senator O'Brien and Senator Jacinta Collins have said in regard to the concept of the part the unions will play and the part that the commission will play in the system. The part that the commission seems to be playing in the scheme, as suggested through the amendments we are talking about, and the use of the word `maintained', is that somehow the commission
itself, without the unions, will be able to do it.

speech.para: Senator Murray has said that that could be initiated by small business, and I think Senator Collins and Senator O'Brien dealt with that. What adds some weight to the way this side of the chamber looks at how the commission is to work under the new system is the deletion of the present section 90AA in the act, which uses similar words to those used in 88A and 88B. The present 90AA(2) reads:
In performing these functions, the commission must:
(a) ensure, so far as it can, that the system of awards provides for a secure, relevant and consistent wages and conditions of employment: and
Under the present act, what that would seem to mean is that, when the commission has the opportunity, as it would if there was a dispute, it ought to do these things.

I was wondering how a court would treat the leaving out of the words `so far as it can' that are in the present act. I would have thought that what they would say is that the whole thrust of 88A, taken with 88B and the fact that 99A(2) is repealed, means that this particular piece of legislation is set up on the basis that the commission itself has somehow the constitutional ability to set minimum wages and standards on its own, which would be a very interesting development in constitutional law.

speech.para: Senator Woodley, I am confident that you are listening and that you would have great sympathy with these amendments. Just convince Senator Murray. . I assume it was an acknowledgment that this is simply a restructuring; and I assume that everything I said, Senator Murray, about you in my previous remarks has been confirmed by that shrug of the shoulders.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —l concur with the parliamentary secretary's response. The argument so far has been a little mischievous because we have indeed won back equal remuneration and that is picked up in a later schedule. On first hearing the argument, pay for remuneration sounds very attractive but it is, in our view, unnecessary because awards provide for rates of pay and the equal remuneration arguments have tended to be about above award—which is what was said earlier—and also cover a wide range of non‐cash benefits. Equal pay is a term long understood and used by the AIRC, and the reference to equal pay in this principle reflects that this division deals only with awards which, by virtue of section 89A(2), are minimum rate awards. We contend that the equal remuneration argument, which you express warmly, is picked up in later schedules.
—In response to Senator Murray, I am interested in his response to the question of training, for example, which is not pay, but the issue of access to training—
—And payment for it.

—And payment for training come in in relation to the definition of equal remuneration. The point that Senator Jacinta Collins has made very strongly is that you simply cannot talk about equal pay full stop in this section without actually excluding a whole series of things, like the access to and payment for training. I have to say that I find it extraordinary that the Democrats have indicated that they will not be supporting the concept of equal remuneration in the Labor Party's amendments. I would like a response from Senator Murray with regard to the issue of training, for example.

—That is not what I said. I said that we have won back equal remuneration. It is back in there, and we took note of the previous Labor act and how it was constituted. Our advice was that this was unnecessary in this section.

—On a point of clarification, I
have actually checked this for Senator Murray. What applied under the current act was not a specific reference to equal pay; it was a principle applied by the commission. There is no provision in the current act under the powers of the commission which refers to either equal pay or equal remuneration, thus my preliminary comments congratulating the Democrats and the government on feeling it was appropriate to address this issue at that stage. The problem is you have not addressed it appropriately. There is a lengthy diatribe of international law on the issue. We refer to equal remuneration because the principle is remuneration. Unfortunately, on this issue, the government and the Democrats have been meddling where they should not be. We cannot introduce into Australian law—internationally we will look like fools—the principle of equal pay at this point in our history. The notion is simply ludicrous.

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para: —I refer to amended section 88B(3) which says:

speech.para: In performing its functions under this Part, the Commission must have regard to the following. . .
One that would interest us all is paragraph (e), which reads:

. . . the need to prevent and eliminate discrimination because of, or for reasons including, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin.
What ability has the commission to do that? I know we have not got to section 89A yet, but if its ability to make awards is limited, how can it perform its obligations under section 88B(3)(e)?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The advice is that by restricting the allowable matters that the commission can rule on, it does not restrict the ability of the commission to have regard to those matters which you have enumerated in (3)(e).

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para:
—I think it is a very admirable requirement in section 88B to have the commission ensure
that that does not happen. It seems to me it is just a general statement of what is a good thing, but it is no more than that, because unless in some way the commission has an ability to enforce its requirement to ensure that these things must be prevented, section 88B(3)(e) becomes a very good statement of the sort of policy we ought to adopt, but it is no more than that.

speech.para: If that is the situation, isn't it a bit hard on the commission to say it must have regard to matters that it cannot really do anything about? Why shouldn't it just say that it may take into account these matters? That, at least, would be a nice statement and would probably better describe what we want to get at.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —The government disagrees, and I think the Democrats disagree, with that position. We believe they must have regard to these important matters when they are performing their functions. It is a matter of emphasis but we certainly prefer the stronger emphasis. I guess you could always move an amendment if you thought we should weaken the commission's regard for these matters.

—I am not saying you should weaken it, but if you were to give the commission wider powers, you would better encompass what I think the government and the Democrats are trying to get to in 88B(3)(e). I think everybody would have to applaud the approach taken in 88B(3)(e). Since everybody applauds that, wouldn't it then be useful, or almost obligatory, to increase the allowable award matters that the commission can take into account, to better encompass the very good ambition that is expressed in 88B(3)(e)? In other words, by limiting the matters that the commission can take into account when making an award, you very much limit the very excellent sentiments expressed in 88B(3)(e).

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role:
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to
the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —We do not think so. We think we can achieve those objectives within those allowable matters. The debate over allowable matters is obviously one that has taken a long time—28 hours to date—and could probably take a hell of a lot longer.

—My question goes to the amended 2(c). It talks about `when adjusting the safety net, the needs of the low paid'. Where are we to find a definition of the needs of the low paid? Specifically, is the commission to have reference to things like average weekly earnings and the poverty line? Do you give guidance as to what that definition means?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —That is a matter for the commission.

—Just following on from that, does that mean that you would envisage a test case in the commission arising out of this provision? Is that the way that you would see this being dealt with as a result of this bill passing?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —This is one of the matters that we want the commission to have concern about and, as I said earlier, not in a frivolous way. We are more concerned about the living standards of the low paid—that is why these provisions seek to protect them with a safety net—than we are about lawyers in the industrial field. We do not want that sort of litigation. It is just a matter that they need to have regard to when they are adjusting the safety net. It is as simple as that. It is not a matter that one would expect litigation on. We would prefer the low paid to do better out of this legislation than will industrial lawyers.

speech.speaker: Hogg, Sen John

talk.start.para:
—I understand what you are saying there, but my point is that this is something that the commission are going to have to take
heed of when the matter is raised with them. It would seem logical to me that there is some sort of direction as to how this principle is to be applied, because at this stage there is no previous concept of what constitutes the needs of low paid.

speech.para: Hence if the parliamentary secretary can give me some more precise advice I would be anxious to get it. There are differences, for example, between a person who is paid an hourly rate and a person who is paid a weekly rate. A person who is paid an hourly rate may be paid for, say, five hours a week whilst a person who is paid a weekly rate gets the full rate of pay. Is the person who is paid for the hourly rate but only employed for five hours deemed to be a low paid person? These are the sorts of vexed questions that I think this legislation is going to throw open. Can the parliamentary secretary help me?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —We genuinely believe the commission will be able to find its own way on those matters and we do not regard it as being something that needs further prescription within the legislation.

—I refer the parliamentary secretary and Senator Murray to the early discussion led by Senator Collins. I also refer you to paragraph 3(e), which seeks to prevent and eliminate discrimination on a range of grounds. One of the grounds which is identified in the second sentence is sex. I also refer you to allowable award matters in reference to school based career paths. In a lot of industries a practice had developed where females were not a dominant sector of the work force for overtime, lower classifications and things of that nature, which led to their total wage package being allocated solely to the males and none to the females, for whatever reasons. That gave rise to the equal pay for equal remuneration debate. In this context, pursuing Senator Collins's line of questioning, with the prevention and elimination of discrimination in paragraph (e) on the grounds of sex, is it therefore fair to conclude that any wages or
conditions relating to discrimination are hence outlawed by paragraph (e) even though it is not expressly identified in paragraph (d)?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I think you would agree with me that the commission would be able to enforce an effective outlawing of that. But with this provision 3(e) working with the other provision then it must have regard to doing that. That is the intention.

—So it is the position of the government and the Democrats that remuneration based reward allocated solely on the grounds of gender or sex is sought to be outlawed in these amendments before us now? I would ask both the parliamentary secretary and Senator Murray to address that question if they might.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I am sorry if I was not clear. The position is that the commission, in making decisions in relation to the allowable matters, should have regard to this. But you have the reverse of the position I put before. I think many people would like to see discrimination based on remuneration abolished, however that is possible. You, through your own experience, Senator Bishop, know that is hard to achieve. But through making decisions in relation to those allowable matters the commission is required to have regard to, in particular, under paragraph 3(e), matters including race, colour, sex, sexual preference and so on.
—I rise on the same matter. Senator Campbell, I am curious—this is not a frivolous question; this is a sincere question—about what the government regards as a definition of `pay'.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role:
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local
Government)

talk.start.para: —There is a difference in the legislation between what which is regarded as pay as an allowable matter, which is a minimum rate of pay, and, in other sections of the act, remuneration and other aspects, including over‐award payments; and that is the essential differential. We really have hoed that ground quite thoroughly. There is really no difference between that question of yours and the question that either you or Senator Jacinta Collins asked some 40 minutes ago.
—Would the definition of `pay', with regard to equal pay—which we are talking about at the moment—include allowances?
—I am advised that allowances are an award matter under a separate head.
—Just to clarify that, the definition of equal pay would include allowances; is that correct?
—To clarify that, that is not what I said.
—I am having great difficulty understanding. Perhaps you could give me a yes or no answer. Perhaps I am a bit dim and could not follow it. Could you restate your response.
—If an allowance was related to work, there would have to be an equal allowance for that equal work.
—So you are saying that, in relation to equal pay, this equal pay provision would include allowances. Are you saying that?
—It could.
—You are saying that. What about bonuses? Are they regarded as pay?
—If it is paid through the award then that provision would apply.
—Senator Campbell, what about the situation with regard to loadings?
—Ditto.

—I just want clarification on something
that is perhaps a little technical. In relation to section 88B as amended, I take it to refer to the performance of the commission's functions after it is seized of jurisdiction to deal with a set of matters in an industrial dispute. The commission would have to have regard to section 89A to establish whether there was an industrial dispute, and only after it had done that would it be referring to section 88B as to how it should perform its functions under the act. Is that correct?

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —That is correct, except to the extent that nothing in section 89A will prevent it from applying the principles spelt out in section 88B as amended.

—I am actually intrigued by this new notion of pay. I would like the parliamentary secretary to refer me to the provisions in the bill which differentiate this new notion of what pay is to include from current industrial practice.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —It is not a new notion; it is an old principle, and we have enshrined the equal pay for equal work in paragraph 3(d) of the matters that the commission must have regard to.

—With respect to the parliamentary secretary, the notion that pay includes things such as allowances is not an established principle. He is right: equal pay for equal work was an established principle until we moved on to equal remuneration for equal work. But the notion of pay that he is trying to bend to fit this new notion of awards is not established industrial principle, and once again I ask you to please provide to us where this new notion of pay is defined in this bill.

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role:
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to
the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —Senator Collins, I think you do misunderstand. It is not the new notion of pay. It is the principle of equal pay for equal work that, under the circumstances described by Senator Mackay, we apply to those other matters.

—With respect, Senator Campbell, you might like to apply it and it might be something that you hope will be applied, but there is no direction in this that it will be applied. That is what I want. That is what women workers want. That is what the Democrats should want. God only knows how you convinced them any differently with respect to awards which include conditions which are part of remuneration.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I notice Senator Murray sitting there in stunned silence. The meaning of the word `pay' in this particular subclause (d) might just have dawned on him. This is a sell-out.
—Are you serious?

—I am serious. I will get to your response in a moment and outline why. This is a sell-out with respect to women workers in Australia. If Senator Murray had listened to Senator Campbell's definition in his answer to the points that Senator Mackay raised, it related to bonuses where it is paid through the award; that is, if it is an allowable award matter. There are an enormous number of bonuses paid to workers in industry that are not award matters. I will try to get some figures on that overnight.
—Why don't you read schedule 8 while you are at it?

—We will get to that. Parliamentary Secretary, you might overnight go and check your definition of `bonuses' because, as we understand the definition you just gave us, the vast majority of bonuses are not paid through the award.
—I didn't say that; why put words into my mouth.

—We will reflect on the
Hansard
overnight. But as I understand your definition in respect of bonuses, the commis
sion will not be able to take into account the very significant amounts of money that are paid to probably millions of workers—we will get the statistics—when determining the issue of equal pay for equal value of work. If you do not believe us, put the word `remuneration' in there. We believe the word `remuneration' does cover this very issue of the extensive over-award payments—bonuses or whatever you may call them—in the award system. Most allowances are in the award, although there would be some allowances that are paid outside the award system. But this critical issue on which Senator Murray has not responded is very important to women workers in Australia. You may have another response, Senator Campbell, and we will let you do that now. But I would certainly like to hear from the Democrats about this matter.
—I want to correct the record: Senator Sherry was out of the chamber when I responded.

—Senator Murray did indicate in his comments that he had received advice or information from the government that the principle of equal remuneration was not necessary in awards. I would be interested in hearing what that argument is. Perhaps either Senator Murray or Senator Campbell could get some advice to that effect. I think the women of Australia would like to hear what that argument is.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —This whole issue has now taken—I do not know how long but probably an hour and a half or two hours.
—This issue has taken half an hour.

—It has been raised continually since the division—you are right, half an hour. It is an important matter. Again, we have an example whereby the government has a position in relation to having a set of allowable matters and to changing the award system to be a safety net that is more narrowly cast than what has occurred under the
previous law. We are here changing the previous law. You do not happen to like that.
—Don't cop out on this principle.
—It is a statement of fact, Senator Collins, that you would prefer to leave the award system as it is today.
—Let's hear the argument.

—This is the argument, Senator Collins. Honourable senators opposite would prefer to leave the award system as it is today. They think that the industrial relations system in Australia is working. We believe that is not the case. You would prefer this section of the bill to be amended back to what it is under the existing act. We happen to think that many aspects of industrial relations in Australia have failed.
—Like equal remuneration.
—We have included equal remuneration in schedule 8. I assure you that we will get to schedule 8 at some stage—hopefully some time before Christmas.
—I can guarantee you that.

—That is very good of you, Senator Sherry, because it is quite clear from your actions that that is all you will guarantee. You are quite clearly going down the path of extending this debate for as long as you possibly can. I welcome a thorough debate on this bill. We have had some substantive questions. Senator Mackay asked a couple of very good questions. They were answered thoroughly. You do not like the answers. I am afraid that, because of the fundamental divide on matters of philosophy and policy on this bill, it is going to be very hard for you to like many of the answers that I give you. Nonetheless we will continue to give you answers.
