debate.sub1.title: Visit of Parliamentary Secretary for Trade to Russia and Central Europe

speech.speaker: Brownhill, Sen David

talker.name: Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para:
—I wish to advise the Senate of the outcomes of my recent visit as Parliamentary Secretary for Trade to Russia and central Europe and to table my report, which I have called
Emerging markets and opportunities for Australia
. I believe the outcomes from the visit will complement the forthcoming report by the parliamentary delegation to Hungary and Poland led by you, Madam President.

speech.para:
There have been striking changes since my 1993 visit to central Europe. My report at that time was called
North, south, east, west
. The aim of my recent visit was to register the government's commitment to expanding trade and investment links with their countries and to finalise government agreements which will help our business people to expand their commercial activities in the region. I am pleased to say that the visit was fruitful on both counts.

There is clearly a strong desire to expand their international links and to diversify sources of investment and imports. The strength of this interest in diversification is a potential asset for Australian companies. In my ministerial meetings, I was told that Australia would need to increase its political investment over the next several years if it aims to take advantage of their emerging commercial opportunities.

In central Europe governments play a major role in shaping the framework for business, particularly for foreign firms. I believe that Australian companies have the relevant skills and products to be able to benefit from this region's growth in the next three to five years. A small number of innovative Australian investors are already demonstrating their capacity to become major players in specific niche markets.

para.break: Apart from their diverse histories, the size of the economies of Russia and central Europe differ so much that the two categories cannot usefully be grouped under one head ing. The combined economy of the Commonwealth of Independent States, of which Russia is the largest member, is approximately the same size as that of all the central European economies combined. Its population of 148 million compares with 60 million in Poland. Russia's global two‐way trade was $US124 billion in 1995. Poland, the largest of the central European economies, recorded $US52 billion.

speech.para: However, I wish to stress that Russia is a composite of many regions. A number of its regions have achieved rapid growth and also established a reputation as being stable and predictable in the application of their rules and regulations. Therefore, potential Australian investors and exporters need to be acutely aware of the political, legal and commercial environment in the regions before entering the markets.

The Australian investors whom I met in the three central European countries stressed the formative stage of these markets and the particular opportunities that the region can present to smaller Australian firms. Their point was that many of the larger European and North American firms can be expected to develop a dominance in their specific market segments as these economies move to a more mature stage. Many of the business people said that the next three to five years offered opportunities to enter a high growth market before the major players became entrenched.

It is realistic to expect sustained economic growth in most central European markets. Poland and the Czech Republic are projected to average five per cent growth in the next five years. Romania achieved seven per cent GDP growth in 1995. The currently strong foreign investor sentiment can be expected to continue. Inflow of foreign direct investment, FDI, has risen significantly in the last two years. FDI into the five countries of the central European free trade area, CEFTA, more than doubled in 1995 to $US9 billion, and Poland surpassed Hungary as the main recipient of regional FDI.

Russia has yet to attract a significant inflow of FDI because potential investors remain concerned about unpredictability in the application of rules, in the level of nationalistic
sentiment, and in the role of extra‐legal organisations. However, a number of regions are attracting a considerable investor interest.

The government and business people, especially in Poland and the Czech Republic, had a strong international outlook. There is a good framework for growth in our trade and investment with this region. We have a good set of double tax and investment protection agreements with most countries. The Australian investors whom I met in the region also stressed some of the advantages of the region for them—a strong industrial skills base in their work forces, especially in engineering and related fields; and the generally good physical infrastructure—as advantages in comparison with most developing country locations.

Joint ventures and service industries have good prospects. Many of the foreign countries establishing operations in central Europe use it as a strategic location for access to an expanded European Union market, once these countries become members. Poland and the Czech Republic already have association agreements with the EU, and membership applications to NATO are under consideration. Those two countries and Hungary are expected to become EU members in the near term.

In each country I sought improved market access for Australian products. In the case of agricultural products, import policy reform is especially sensitive in Russia, Poland and Romania. There are serious political constraints on rapid liberalisation given the large proportion of their populations remaining in rural areas.

However, I received a more positive response on issues of concern to foreign business. The main ones are the unpredictability in the application of laws and regulations, the legal framework, uncertainty about property rights, delays in processing applications, and the role of either state‐owned countries or their privatised equivalents.

Some of the Australian companies I contacted have a strategic plan for expansion into the regional markets. For example, Mincom and Brambles are going into the Czech Republic—for Brambles, it is their biggest
overseas contract—and Easycall into Poland. In the food and beverages sector, Australia's Coca‐Cola Amatil identified Romania as one of its 20 top growth markets and has invested over $US131 million in plant and distribution. ADI and Pioneer International have done well in the area of environmental clean‐up.

The privatisation of large numbers of public sector organisations has generated special demands for market relevant skills because many of these organisations are being weaned off government. Business opportunities are flowing from the market liberalisation, the growth of consumer spending, their own skills gap and the international orientation of many local business houses.

Yet Australian companies are, regrettably, scarce on the ground. I believe that a more concerted effort is needed to ensure that Australia does not miss the central European economic take‐off. The low awareness level in Australia about market opportunities in the region appears to be a key weakness.

The central European desire to diversify the sources of investment and imports is an asset for Australia. So is the presence of significant migrant communities in Australia from those countries, which means that we have a pool of relevant linguistic skills and cultural awareness on which business can draw.

The federal government will continue to contribute to improving the level of business awareness of the region through the programs carried out by Austrade and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I believe that a concerted Team Australia approach will be needed in the next several years, involving government agencies working closely with major industry associations to ensure that Australia does not miss out on the commercial opportunities which are emerging as these countries achieve sustained economic growth. I table a copy of the report,
Emerging markets and opportunities for Australia
.

speech.speaker: Hogg, Sen John

talk.start.para:
—I rise tonight to speak about some very sad circumstances that have arisen in the state of Queensland. In recent times we have seen once again interference in the judicial
system, this time through interference with the CJC. It really is quite sad that Queensland has gone back to the days which existed pre‐Fitzgerald. I had hoped that we would have had a maturing of the government in Queensland, after they had been out of office for some six years. Instead, when the going got too hot, the CJC and the inquiry conducted by Ken Carruthers were interfered with. I do not say that lightly. I have here a statement by Ken Carruthers, a former Supreme Court judge, and I quote from part of it:

speech.para: On October the 24th, I received a letter from Mr Hanger, Senior Counsel Assisting the Connolly Ryan inquiry, which said, `There exists the distinct possibility that the conduct of your inquiries will be a matter to be considered by this commission of inquiry.'
I will just depart from that statement. That is the commission of inquiry established by the Borbidge government in Queensland. The statement of Carruthers goes on:

I regarded these approaches as an assertion of control over the conduct of my inquiry by Mr Hanger and Mr Simon Cooper on behalf of the commission which they were assisting. Salient points of a legal opinion include: although it is part of my duty to recommend whether criminal charges should be brought against the Premier, Mr Borbidge and the Minister for Police, Mr Cooper, among others, both are members of the government which established the Connolly Ryan commission.
The next dot point in his statement reads:
In other words, two people, into whose conduct and possible misconduct I am inquiring, have participated in the setting up of an inquiry into my inquiry into them.'
This, I believe, is quite a disgusting set of circumstances.

talk.start.para: —Shameful!

—As my colleague has just interjected, it is shameful. One would have thought that the Carruthers inquiry would have been allowed to go to its natural conclusion and then we would have had unfolded before us whether there were people culpable as a result of that inquiry and subject to charges under the laws of the state of Queensland. But not so. We found that the honourable person conducting the inquiry, a respected person, found himself in the position
where he had no choice in his mind but to resign.

speech.para: It is interesting to also then look at some of the follow‐up material that has come out as a result of the fracas that has taken place in the state of Queensland. A letter to the editor on the day following sums up the whole position very well. This letter says:

The resignation of Mr Carruthers QC should be the cause for great alarm in our community. Whether or not the CJC is deserving of an inquiry into its own operation—and many would say it is—the timing of that inquiry certainly leads one to question the motivation for it at this time. One irresistible view is that it was established in an attempt to cast doubt on the findings made by Mr Carruthers and thus protect or seek to protect the premier, his police minister and others, from criminal prosecution. These latest revelations, which place Mr Carruthers in such an extraordinary dilemma, are to be deplored.
The letter goes on:
While both these men are highly regarded for their ability and integrity
—that is, Messrs Connolly and Ryan, who are conducting the inquiry into the inquiry—
it is surely cause for some surprise that Mr Connolly accepted the position as joint head of the inquiry given his previous professional involvement with the police minister—not a wise decision.

It is with regret that I stand here before you and this honourable Senate to contemplate what is happening in the state of Queensland. Where has fairness gone? Where has objectivity gone? If one is guilty, if one has to face the music, then surely one must have the courage to do so. If—and I say if—the Carruthers inquiry was allowed to proceed, one does not know what the outcome would have been.

It would equally have been responsible for the government in Queensland, if the CJC is worthy of some form of rigorous inquiry, if the CJC has in some way stepped beyond its charter, stepped beyond the realms of what is reasonable in a society, to have postponed the inquiry into the CJC until after the Carruthers inquiry had finished. But no, what we saw was a return to the good old days—the return to save mates and the return to protect their friends. This, of course, has led to a lack of
confidence by the Queensland people in the state government.

After the lengthy period that was spent in dealing with corruption in the state of Queensland, it is surely a sad day when we see what is emerging today. Obviously, people have not learnt from these lessons. There will be other occasions on which I will make further reference to this matter. I wanted to draw to the attention of senators, this Senate and those listening this evening, that over the weekend the people in Queensland, in my view, expressed their dissatisfaction at the way this whole activity has proceeded.

Whilst there are moves in the state of Queensland today, the outcome of which I am not aware, one would hope that, in the end, sanity will prevail, that people will see that justice is done—not only that it has to be done—and that it will be delivered in a fair, equitable and reasonable manner having due regard to the needs of the people in the state of Queensland.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para: —I rise to continue a debate that I have been having with the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Amanda Vanstone. In fact, last week in this place, I raised the issue of figures that were used in the 1996 higher education budget statement to justify HECS increases by the coalition government. The coalition presented a higher education budget which, according to the estimates committee hearings of the Senate, demands that students contribute up to as much as 60 per cent—potentially 80 per cent in some cases—of their course costs.

speech.para: Examples from the government's higher education statement actually can include courses such as law and medicine—those courses in the highest band. So, contrary to evidence presented by the minister, we actually have the potential for course costs for individual student contributions in this country to be among the highest in the world—certainly the highest in the Western World, if not the highest in the world after Korea. I presented that evidence last week.

break.para: The issue that we seem to have been embroiled in—both in question time today and last week and on the adjournment debate last Thursday—is the OECD figures that I used to demonstrate that the minister had been using rubbery figures. She had been using incorrect statistics to prove her case.

In Senate question time today, the minister actually conceded that the position the Australian Democrats put to the chamber last week was in fact correct and that the OECD statistics she used in the 1996 higher education budget statement were wrong. The figures in question were actually used in section 2 of the budget statement, entitled `Fair balance between public and private funding'. Page 8 of the budget statement claimed that the average proportion of 23 per cent—that is, 23 per cent of individual course contributions—is:

. . . substantially lower than the rate of private contribution to higher education in a number of comparable countries. For example, recent OECD statistics show that on average students in the United States contribute around half of the cost of their course, while Japanese students around 60 per cent and students in Denmark contribute 40 per cent.

So an OECD table claiming that Danish students contributed 40 per cent of the cost of their education was used to justify this government's decision to increase course costs. The OECD report in question,
Education at a Glance
, actually states on page 108:

The private shares of final education expenditures are higher than the initial shares because the former reflect funds that are transferred to as well as generated in the private sector; the former are found mainly in the forms of scholarships and other subsidies for students.

The private shares of expenditures (for all levels of education combined) after transfers range from 7.0 per cent in Canada to 8.8 per cent in France to over 24% in both the United States and Japan. The Nordic Countries, the Netherlands and Australia have very small initial private shares, but substantial private shares after transfers.
It continues:

The final private shares of tertiary spending are sharply higher than initial private shares in most cases. For example, the initial and final private shares in Denmark are 1.2% and 37.9%, respectively. The differences are accounted for by public subsidies to students or households.
Those figures are 1.2 per cent and 37.9 per cent respectively. Yet the coalition and the minister in their budget statement chose only to quote the 40 per cent figure.

Since my question last week in this place, and after the OECD actually informed the minister's department that they are not even going to use this table in future publications, the minister has admitted both in an adjournment debate last week and in question time today that her higher education budget statement relied on `messy statistics'. Today in Senate question time, Minister Vanstone conceded that the figures for Denmark, Japan and the United States were all invalid. So this issue has now been resolved.

But one issue remains. These figures were used by the government, contrary to the minister's claims in here today, to justify the government's policy changes in relation to higher education—in particular, the increase in HECS and other fees and charges.

I would like to draw on the relevant section of the government's budget statement, `Fair balance between public and private funding', which I previously referred to—that is, section 2. On the same page as the OECD figures I previously quoted, the statement says:
. . . it is clear that the private benefits of university graduation are substantially greater than the notional level implied by . . . HECS.

Yet the minister said today in this place that the OECD figures were not used to justify the HECS increases. This quote indicates that the coalition believed the current levels to be notional—an assertion that many potential students would, I suspect, agree with, especially those students who have decided not to continue or enter higher education as a result of this government's prohibitive course cost changes. I am sure those people would dispute the idea that they are notional charges, despite the minister's claim today in this place. The statement continues:
The Government therefore believes that a higher level of HECS charge is justified.
The second quote from there states:

The Government also believes that, in setting the level of the HECS charge, consideration should be given to both the actual cost of the course under
taken and the likely future benefits to the individual in terms of increased life‐time earnings.

That is from page 8 of the budget statement. It clearly refers to the OECD statistics as being a justification for course cost increases. The coalition has indeed used rubbery figures as a basis to turn Australia into the most expensive place to undertake public university and higher education. The fact that they used messy statistics is of little comfort to those many university aspirants and students at this time.

The Australian Democrats did not accept the minister's figures at the time. We did not accept her figures in the budget. We did not accept her explanation or justification last week. Nor do we accept this government's policy change to increase HECS.

Now that the minister and this government—and in fact the OECD—seem to have discarded these figures, we are arguing that the HECS charges and the other regressive budget policy measures in relation to higher education should similarly be discarded. I look forward to the minister's response on this evidence that I think is pretty irrefutable.

speech.speaker: Forshaw, Sen Michael

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to speak regarding two matters—one is a celebration; the other one, unfortunately, could well be an impending devastation. I want to speak about the community of Helensburgh, a town situated south of Sydney in the Royal National Park. Helensburgh has been a very close‐knit community for well over 100 years. It has the distinction of being one of the few areas within the Royal National Park where persons are permitted to live. As I said, it has been a very close‐knit community.

speech.para:
On 9 November this year, the Helensburgh Workmen's Club will celebrate its 100th anniversary. The workers club was first formed at a meeting of a group of miners back in November 1896. The miners met to establish the club because they resented the attitude of the publicans who ran the local hotels at the time. As a result of that meeting they resolved to establish the Helensburgh and Lilyvale Workmen's Club and Mutual
School of Arts. I am advised that in present day currency, the entrance fee was 25c, with a quarterly subscription of 12c. Obviously, if you paid by the year you got a discount. In its early days, the club struggled to compete against the local publicans. The miners, in the great tradition of mining workers of this country, banded together and kept the club going.

I also understand that the motto of the club in the early days of its existence was `Taste and try before you buy'. Apparently this was a reasonably cheap means of increasing the rather meagre revenue for the club. Within a 14‐month period in 1903‐1904, the committee of the workers club had written for and sampled, free of charge, no fewer than 11 different wines as well as a range of beers. If nothing else, the committee of the club at the time showed a great sense of ingenuity.

The club was not only a place for a quiet drink and a chat with your mates but also a place where one could listen to lectures given by prominent members of the labour movement. I am reading from an article in the
Worker's Journal
. I am also advised that the great Australian poet and balladeer Henry Lawson was a regular visitor to and speaker at the club.

The club has gone on to bigger and better things. Last Saturday extensions to the workers club at Helensburgh were opened by Gough Whitlam. When Gough Whitlam first entered parliament he was the member for Werriwa. In those days the seat of Werriwa stretched from about Wollongong in the south, from Cabramatta and the Liverpool area in the west, through to Cronulla on the coast. Helensburgh was one of the many areas in the electorate that had a strong Labor and union presence.

It was great to go down to Helensburgh on Saturday and see the people of the town taking pride in their history and in the important role that the workers club plays—like many other clubs in New South Wales and other states—in its local community. I was certainly very privileged to be there, not specifically as an official guest but rather as a person who has often visited that quiet lovely area within the national park. Sadly,
after the celebrations on Saturday, I paid a visit to a picket line at a Helensburgh colliery called the Metropolitan Colliery, which is run by the company Denehurst. The picket line was established by the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union because of the impending closure of the colliery. It was sadly ironic that on the same day that we were celebrating the establishment of that club which was created by the miners, we also had this impending devastation facing the workers at the colliery and, indeed, the community. The colliery still employs about 150 workers and is an integral part of the work force of the township and, indeed, of the great history and tradition of this town.

The company Denehurst has placed the colliery into voluntary administration. I understand that a meeting will be held as early as tomorrow to determine the fate of the mine. Unfortunately, there is every prospect that the mine will be closed. I hope that does not happen. The community and, of course, the workers do not want that to happen. It will have some devastating consequences, not only on these workers' employment but also on a lot of other families and on the community that depends very much on the existence of this colliery.

It was appropriate that just before the adjournment debate we were debating the provisions of the workplace relations bill. The attitude adopted by the company on this issue has been nothing short of disgraceful. They had entered into an agreement with the miners federation not so long ago with respect to a continuation of the wages and working conditions, et cetera that applied at this site. As I understand it, they had also signed an agreement with respect to bonuses. Only a couple of weeks ago the union went in to negotiate with the mine management about the level of bonuses for the ensuing period. The response they got was, `There is no point talking to us now because we have just placed the mine in the hands of an administrator.'

There is no doubt that it has been due to the very bad financial and planning management of the company that the colliery has reached this stage. The workers at Metropolitan Colliery have proved themselves amongst the
best, if not the best, in terms of producing record tonnages of coal far exceeding the expectations of the colliery management and what those workers were told at the time was required in tonnages to ensure that the pit would remain profitable.

The workers have done their part to keep this colliery operating. There are still substantial recoverable resources of coal in the colliery. But, unfortunately, because of bad management, the company has got itself into a situation of debt and it appears that the ultimate losers will be the workers. If the mine is closed, 150 workers will be retrenched. Also it appears that there is no money available to pay out the retrenchment pay as well as long service leave, holiday pay and other considerations. Somewhere in the vicinity of $2.4 million would be owed to these workers if that sad situation were to eventuate.

I just finish by saying that here we have an example of bad management and also an arrogant disregard by a company for the fate of its workers; workers who have not only worked in one of the most strenuous industries in this country but have also put a heck of a lot into a local community.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —I wish to again draw the attention of the Senate to the matter of literacy in Australian schools and to the ongoing remarks of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) to the effect that 30 per cent of Australian 14‐year‐olds lack basic literacy skills.

speech.para:
As the Senate will know, the data on which the minister so irresponsibly based his claims was not a literacy test at all. It was a small part of a 20‐year longitudinal study of the transition from school to work of a group of young Australians. Not only was the test irrelevant to the minister's claims, but the study is not due to be finished until next year. Even after this had been pointed out to the minister, he continued to accuse schools of hiding the data. He said parents were entitled to know their children did not have basic literacy skills. In short, he continued to
scaremonger, to put fear into the hearts of every parent with children in school.
This morning we heard more of the story on Radio National. Commentator and journalist Brian Toohey was asked how he thought the minister would have handled the test himself. He said:

The test is incredibly difficult and it is totally misleading to suggest that what most people would regard as lacking in basic literacy skills, was actually being tested here. For example, I think there's a strong suggestion that people can't get a job. Maybe when they're a storeman and packer they're told to go and get 12 boxes of Kelloggs and they come back with 12 boxes of Uncle Toby's or whatever. It's not testing that sort of thing, it's testing some very difficult questions about, in one case, a passage of writing about war which is really an extended metaphor.

Brian Toohey put the test to its author, Melbourne
Age
journalist Martin Flanagan. The test said:
The story the writer tells us suggests the causes of war are often complex, invisible, justifiable or insignificant.

That was the question. Mr Flanagan answered with the word `complex'. That is what he meant to suggest when he wrote that piece. But the examiner, in this case, came up with quite a different answer. To get 100 per cent on this part of the test, the student had to say that the causes of war are often insignificant. Martin Flanagan says that is the last thing that he intended. But the very question and the use of the word `suggests' gives the game away. As Brian Toohey says, `It is not a matter of what the author said; it is a matter of what he was suggesting.'

There is nothing unusual about this kind of test of comprehension. Such a test is meant to be difficult and to make students think. You might well argue that the examiner's interpretation was incorrect, but who knows? In tests of comprehension, the answers are very often not black and white. It is not like finding out if a student can read, where you can say he or she can recognise and read that word or sentence. Comprehension is an entirely different matter.

This comprehension test, which the minister deliberately chooses to pass off as a test of literacy, is in fact a concept called mastery.
Back in 1975, when I understand the test was started, you had to get 80 per cent to pass.

Will the minister now attempt to blame his advisers for this debacle? Mr Toohey offers the view—and I am very much inclined to agree—that the minister, who has a PhD from Yale University, should have known better. He says the minister has the gall to talk about 14‐year‐old students failing.

The minister has been the instigator of a beat‐up of the most appalling sort: `shock findings', `alarming' and `a major cause of Australia's high youth unemployment'. As Mr Toohey points out, shock findings are not the cause of anything and they are certainly not the cause of youth unemployment.

So what is the problem of literacy that schools and teachers in this country are dealing with? I do not say it is not a problem. But I think it is extremely unlikely that the problem is worse now than it has been in the past, and there is plenty of evidence to show that literacy levels have improved over time.

If the minister were not in such a hurry to make these alarmist pronouncements, we might be in a better position, if we have a problem, to understand its extent and how it might be addressed. The minister is well aware that we are now in the middle of the national survey of literacy. This survey was designed to provide the minister with just the sort of information that he says he needs to form policy.

This morning Senator Vanstone changed the government's tack somewhat. She now claims that there have been no improvements in literacy skills over the past 30 years. This leads me to wonder what sort of research the minister now draws upon to reach this latest conclusion. It falls a long way short of an apology and it certainly does not repair the damage that has been already done.

Let us return to the government's commitment to literacy in this country. The Senate will have seen the budget papers and seen that $45 million is to be provided by the federal government for a literacy program. The government is making much of this commitment. I need to point out, however, that this $45 million works out to be about $5 per student per annum. I sincerely hope that this
amount will be useful but I suggest that we should not hold out too much hope. There is one truth about literacy; that is, that there is no simple answer to the question of how children best learn to read and write. In any case, it is not all that we expect them to be able to do.

Undoubtedly there are students who are not literate when they leave primary school. I have taught some of these children. There are very complex reasons for their failure to grasp what their peers do with some ease. If the answer was as simple as to reschedule more English classes, doesn't the minister think that schools would simply do this? Why some children do not learn to read as well as others is a complex question—and so is the remedy. You cannot force children to learn and you cannot force them to value knowledge.

Why is it that some parents read to their children from infancy and provide them with books—and others do not? Why is it that even this is not an absolute indicator of literacy levels in school? It would make much more sense for the government to stop making these wild pronouncements, to stop bashing teachers and schools, to stop alarming parents with such outrageous claims and to work towards the common goal of improving educational opportunities and improving outcomes for our students.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 June 1996:

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

question.speaker: Senator Allison

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 14 October 1996:

question.para: (1) Were a number of signs advertising cigarettes visible 10 days after the 1995 Melbourne Grand Prix, in breach of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act; if so, is this breach of the Act regarded as acceptable.
(2) Will it be recommended that the organisers of the Australian Grand Prix be prosecuted for the breach; if not, why not.
(3) If this event was regarded as a tolerable breach of the Act, what constitutes an intolerable breach of the Act.
(4) What action is the Government taking to prevent a repeat of such a breach.
(5) Did the Government investigate the tobacco regulations in other nations prior to agreeing to allowing tobacco advertising at the Australian Grand Prix.

(6)(a) As part of these investigations, did the Government consider the option taken by certain European nations to allow the advertising of the colours, but not the names, of tobacco companies; and (b) why did the Government reject this model for Australia.

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: — The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Health and Family Services has received reports of four overhead tobacco advertising signs remaining after the event. Although the signs had been covered with a thin layer of whitewash, the signs were still visible.

The exemption period which was specified in the gazette notice of 21 September 1995, permitted signs to remain in place for seven days after the event. In effect, the signs were visible only for three days past the exemption date.
(2) Although the advertising signs in question were, prima facie, in breach of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992, it was decided that prosecution was not appropriate in this instance.
A prosecution is a long and expensive process, and court action is only really appropriate if it will yield a net benefit to the community.
The decision not to prosecute was made on the advice received from the Attorney‐General's Department and the Director of Public Prosecutions.

(3) The Commonwealth generally only proceeds with a prosecution where it can be established that court action will yield a net benefit to the community and where lesser measures are not sufficient to ensure compliance with the Act.
(4) Any future granting of a section 18 exemption to the Grand Prix Association will be made contingent upon a clarification of this matter, and an assurance that no further breaches will occur.

(5) The Minister of Health and Family Services is aware that a small number of countries impose more stringent restrictions on tobacco advertising in association with the Grand Prix. However it should be noted that, Australia has amongst the most stringent controls over all forms of tobacco advertising anywhere in the world.

(6) The Minister is not in a position to comment upon the specific details of the exemption granted to the 1996 Australian Formula One Grand Prix, including why the previous Government choose to reject a particular option.
The Minister is not aware of any evidence as to the overall effectiveness of limiting tobacco sponsorship to brand colours compared to our current requirements.

The exemption granted to the 1996 Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix restricted tobacco advertising to a limited number of signs and required that health warnings accompany all static signs. If consideration were to be given to moving to the product colours model it may preclude the current requirement to have accompanying health warnings with signs.
